revision.text:
{{Infobox MP | name = Aamir Mehmood Kiani | honorific-suffix = |image = | office = [[Ministry of National Health Services, Regulation and Coordination|Federal Minister for National Health Services, Regulation and Coordination]] |president = [[Mamnoon Hussain]]
[[Arif Alvi]] |primeminister = [[Imran Khan]] | predecessor = Muhammad Yusuf Shaikh (caretaker) | term_start = 20 August 2018 | term_end = | office1 =Member of the [[National Assembly of Pakistan]] | term_start1 = 13 August 2018 | term_end1 = |constituency1 = [[NA-61 (Rawalpindi-V)]] | birth_date = | birth_place = |nationality = Pakistani |party = [[Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf]] }} '''Aamir Mehmood Kiani''' ({{lang-ur|{{nq|عامر محمود کیانی}}}}) is a Pakistani politician who is the current [[Ministry of National Health Services, Regulation and Coordination|Federal Minister for National Health Services, Regulation and Coordination]], in office since 20 August 2018. He has been a member of the [[National Assembly of Pakistan]] since August 2018. ==Political career== He was elected to the [[National Assembly of Pakistan]] as a candidate of [[Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf]] (PTI) from Constituency [[NA-61 (Rawalpindi-V)]] in [[Pakistani general election, 2018]].{{cite news |title=Amir Mehmood Kiani of PTI wins NA-61 election |url=https://www.app.com.pk/amir-mehmood-kiani-of-pti-wins-na-61-election/ |accessdate=2 August 2018 |work=Associated Press Of Pakistan |date=26 July 2018}} He received 105,000 votes and defeated [[Malik Ibrar Ahmed]].{{cite web |title=NA-61 Result - Election Results 2018 - Rawalpindi 5 - NA-61 Candidates - NA-61 Constituency Details - thenews.com.pk |url=https://www.thenews.com.pk/election/constituency/NA-61 |website=www.thenews.com.pk |accessdate=2 August 2018 |language=en}} On 18 August, [[Imran Khan]] formally announced his federal cabinet structure and Kiani was named as [[Ministry of National Health Services, Regulation and Coordination|Minister for National Health Services, Regulations and Coordination]].{{cite news |title=PM Imran Khan finalises names of 21-member cabinet |url=https://www.dawn.com/news/1427792/pm-imran-khan-finalises-names-of-21-member-cabinet |accessdate=18 August 2018 |work=DAWN.COM |date=18 August 2018}} On 20 August 2018, he was sworn in as Federal Minister for National Health Services, Regulations and Coordination in the federal cabinet of Prime Minister Imran Khan.{{cite news |title=16 ministers from PM Imran Khan's cabinet sworn in |url=https://www.dawn.com/news/1428169/16-ministers-from-pm-imran-khans-cabinet-sworn-in |accessdate=20 August 2018 |work=DAWN.COM |date=20 August 2018}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} {{Khan Cabinet}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Pakistani MNAs 2018–23]] {{Pakistan-politician-stub}}

revision.text:
{{About|a Greek philosopher|the book by Gottlob Ernst Schulze|Aenesidemus (book)|the tyrant of Leontini|Aenesidemus, tyrant of Leontini}} {{more footnotes|date=February 2013}} {{Infobox philosopher | region = [[Western philosophy]] | era = [[Ancient philosophy]] | image = | caption = | name = Aenesidemus | birth_date = 1st century BC | birth_place = [[Knossos]] | school_tradition = [[Pyrrhonism]] | main_interests = [[Epistemology]], [[Metaphysics]], [[Ethics]] | notable_ideas = [[Epoché]] | influences = [[Pyrrho]], [[Timon (philosopher)|Timon]], [[Heraclitus]] | influenced = [[Sextus Empiricus]], [[Favorinus]], [[Plutarch]] }} '''Aenesidemus''' ({{lang-grc|Αἰνησίδημος}} or {{lang-grc|Αἰνεσίδημος}}) was a [[Greece|Greek]] [[Pyrrhonism|Pyrrhonist]] philosopher, born in [[Knossos]] on the island of [[Crete]]. He lived in the 1st century BC, taught in [[Alexandria]] and flourished shortly after the life of [[Cicero]]. [[Photios I of Constantinople|Photius]] saysA. A. Long,D. N. Sedley, The Hellenistic Philosophers, 1987, p 469. he was a member of [[Plato's Academy]], but he came to dispute their theories, adopting [[Pyrrhonism]] instead. [[Diogenes Laertius]] claims an unbroken lineage of teachers of Pyrrhonism through Aenesidemus, with his teacher being [[Heraclides of Tarentum|Heraclides]].http://www.classicpersuasion.org/pw/diogenes/dltimon.htm However, little is known about the names between [[Timon of Phlius]] and Aenesidemus, so this lineage is suspect. Whether Aenesidemus re-founded the Pyrrhonist school or merely revitalized it is unknown. == Life == There is no definite evidence about the life of Aenesidemus, but his most important work, the ''Pyrrhoneia'' was known to be dedicated to Lucius Tubero, a friend of [[Cicero]] and member of [[Plato's Academy]] whom Photius described as a colleague. Based on this information, scholars have assumed that Aenesidemus himself was also a member of the Academy. Furthermore, it has been assumed that he took part under the leadership of [[Philo of Larissa]] and probably adopted Pyrrhonism either in reaction to [[Antiochus of Ascalon]] introduction of [[Stoicism|Stoic]] and [[Peripatetic school|Peripatetic]] [[dogma]] into the [[Academy]] or Philo's acceptance of provisional beliefs. What little we know of Aenesidemus is by way of [[Photios I of Constantinople|Photius]] (in his ''[[Bibliotheca (Photius)|Myriobiblion]]''), [[Sextus Empiricus]], and also to a lesser extent by [[Diogenes Laertius]] and [[Philo of Alexandria]]. == Pyrrhoneia == His chief work, known in Ancient Greek as ''Pyrrhôneoi logoi'' (Πυρρώνειοι λóγοι) and often rendered into English as the "Pyrrhonian Discourses" or "Pyrrhonian Principles", dealt primarily with man's need to suspend judgment due to our [[epistemology|epistemological]] limitations. It was divided into eight books, but it has not survived. We have this summary of its contents from [[Photios I of Constantinople|Photius]] (in his ''[[Bibliotheca (Photius)|Myriobiblion]]'').
I read Aenesidemus' eight ''Pyrrhonist Discourses.'' The overall aim of the book is to establish that there is no firm basis for cognition, either through sense-perception, or indeed through thought. Consequently, he says, neither the Pyrrhonists nor the others know the truth in things; but the philosophers of other persuasions, as well as being ignorant in general, and wearing themselves out uselessly and expending themselves in ceaseless torments, are also ignorant of the very fact that they have cognition of none of the things of which they think that they have gained cognition. But he who philosophizes after the fashion of Pyrrho is happy not only in general but also, and especially, in the wisdom of knowing that he has firm cognition of nothing. And even with regard to what he knows, he has the propriety to assent no more to its affirmation than to its denial. The whole scheme of the book is directed towards the purpose I have mentioned. In writing the discourses Aenesidemus addresses them to Lucius Tubero, one of his colleagues from the Academy, a Roman by birth, with an illustrious ancestry and a distinguished political career. In the first discourse he differentiates between the Pyrrhonists and the Academics in almost precisely the following words. He says that the Academics are doctrinaire: they posit some things with confidence and unambiguously deny others. The Pyrrhonists, on the other hand, are aporetic and free of all doctrine. Not one of them has said either that all things are incognitive, or that they are cognitive, but that they are no more of this kind than of that, or that they are sometimes of this kind, sometimes not, or that for one person they are of this kind, for another person not of this kind, and for another person not even existent at all. Nor do they say that all things in general, or some things, are accessible to us, or not accessible to us, but that they are no more accessible to us than not, or that they are sometimes accessible to us, sometimes not, or that they are accessible to one person but not to another. Nor indeed, do they say there is true or false, convincing or unconvincing, existent or non-existent. But the same thing is, it might be said, no more true than false, convincing than unconvincing, or existent or non-existent; or sometimes the one, sometimes the other; or of such a kind for one person but not for another. For the Pyrrhonist determines absolutely nothing, not even this very claim that nothing is determined. (We put it this way, he says, for lack of a way to express the thought.) But the Academics, he says, especially those from the present-day Academy, are sometimes in agreement with Stoic beliefs, and to tell the truth turn out to be Stoics fighting with Stoics. Moreover, they are doctrinaire about many things. For they introduce virtue and folly, and posit good and bad, truth and falsity, convincing and unconvincing, existent and non-existent. They give firm determinations for many other things too. It is only about the cognitive impression that they express dissent. Thus the followers of Pyrrho, in determining nothing, remain absolutely above reproach, whereas the Academics, he says, incur a scrutiny similar to that faced by the other philosophers. Above all, the Pyrrhonists, by entertaining doubts about every thesis, maintain consistency and do not conflict with themselves, whereas the Academics are unaware that they are conflicting with themselves. For to make unambiguous assertions and denials, at the same time as stating as a generalization that no things are cognitive, introduces an undeniable conflict: how is it possible to recognize that this is true, this false, yet still entertain perplexity and doubt, and not make a clear choice of the one and avoidance of the other? For if it is not known that this is good or bad, or that this is true but that false, and this existent but that non-existent, it must certainly be admitted that each of them is incognitive. But if they receive self-evident cognition by means of sense-perception or thought, we must say that each is cognitive. These similar considerations are set out by Aenesidemus of Aegae at the beginning of his discourses, to indicate the difference between the Pyrrhonists and Academics. He goes on in the same discourse, the first, also to report in summary outline the entire way of life of the Pyrrhonists.
== The Ten Tropes of Aenesidemus == The reasons for ''epoché'' are given in what are often called the ten tropes or ten modes, which Sextus Empiricus attributed to Aenesidemus. These are as follows: # Different animals manifest different modes of perception; # Similar differences are seen among individual men; # For the same man, information perceived with the senses is self-contradictory # Furthermore, it varies from time to time with physical changes # In addition, this data differs according to local relations # Objects are known only indirectly through the medium of air, moisture, etc. # These objects are in a condition of perpetual change in colour, temperature, size and motion # All perceptions are relative and interact one upon another # Our impressions become less critical through repetition and custom # All men are brought up with different beliefs, under different laws and social conditions In other words, Aenesidemus argues that experience varies infinitely under circumstances whose importance to one another cannot be accurately judged by human observers. He therefore rejects any concept of absolute knowledge of reality, since every each person has different perceptions, and they arrange their sense-gathered data in methods peculiar to themselves. == Heraclitean view == Either in the ''Pyrrhonian discourses'' or some other work that did not survive, Aenesidemus assimilated the theories of [[Heraclitus]], as is discussed in the ''Outlines of Pyrrhonism'' of [[Sextus Empiricus]]. For admitting that contraries co-exist for the perceiving subject, he was able to assert the co-existence of contrary qualities in the same object. == See also == * [[Agrippa the Sceptic]] * [[Arcesilaus]] * [[Carneades]] * [[Pyrrho]] * [[Sextus Empiricus]] == Notes == {{reflist|refs= {{EB1911|inline=1|wstitle=Aenesidemus|volume=1|pages=257-258}} This cites: * [[Eduard Zeller|Zeller]]'s History of Greek Philosophy * [[Émile Saisset|E. Saisset]], ''Ænésidème, Pascal, Kant'' * [[Heinrich Ritter|Ritter]] and [[Ludwig Preller|Preller]], §§ 364-870. }} == References == * {{citation| last = Caizzi| first = Fernanda Decleva| title = Aenesidemus and the Academy| journal = The Classical Quarterly| volume = 42| issue = 1| year = 1992| pages = 176–189| doi=10.1017/s0009838800042671}} * Polito, Roberto. ''The Sceptical Road: Aenesidemus' Appropriation of Heraclitus'', Leiden: Brill, 2004. * {{citation| last = Thorsrud| first = Harold| title = Ancient Greek Skepticism| newspaper = The Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy| url = http://www.iep.utm.edu/s/skepanci.htm| accessdate = 23 June 2007}} == External links == * {{cite IEP |url-id=a/aeneside.htm |title=Aenesidemus}} {{Ancient Greek skepticism}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Aenesidemus}} [[Category:Ancient Cretan philosophers]] [[Category:Ancient Knossians]] [[Category:Ancient Skeptic philosophers]] [[Category:Epistemologists]] [[Category:1st-century BC Greek people]] [[Category:1st-century BC writers]] [[Category:Year of birth unknown]] [[Category:Year of death unknown]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox cave | name =Bray's Cave | other_name = | photo = | photo_width = | photo_caption = | map = | map_width = | map_caption = Map showing location in [[Gibraltar]]. | map_alt = | location = [[Upper Rock Nature Reserve]], [[Gibraltar]] | coords = {{coord missing|Gibraltar}} | lat_d = | long_d = | coords_ref = | land_registry_number = | grid_ref_UK = | grid_ref_Ireland = | grid_ref = | depth = | length = | height_variation = | elevation = {{convert|400|m}} | discovery = | geology = [[limestone]] | entrance_count = 1 | entrance_list = | difficulty = | hazards = | access = | show_cave = No | show_cave_length = | lighting = None | visitors = | features = | survey = | survey_format = | website = }} '''Bray's Cave''' is a [[solutional cave|limestone cave]] in the [[British Overseas Territories|British Overseas Territory]] of [[Gibraltar]]. Human remains and notable Neolithic and Bronze Age finds have been unearthed in the cave. Three almost complete skulls were recovered but the important find was that people had returned to the site to re-use it for funerals, other cranial fragments from other individuals were recovered, and it appeared that previous remains had been move aside for a more recent death.<ref name="GrantFibiger2011">{{cite book|last1=Grant|first1=Nicholas Marquez|last2=Fibiger|first2=Linda|title=The Routledge Handbook of Archaeological Human Remains and Legislation|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Lzi4N-74QmAC&pg=PA703|accessdate=17 January 2013|date=21 March 2011|publisher=Taylor & Francis|isbn=978-1-136-87956-2|page=703}}</ref>
==Description== Bray's Cave is located at a height of {{convert|400|m}} above sea level on the western slopes of the [[Rock of Gibraltar]], within the [[Upper Rock Nature Reserve]]. It is important to note its location on the western slopes of the Rock where caves are far less common than on the eastern cliffs where [[sea cave]]s like [[Gorham's Cave]] or [[Vanguard Cave]] for example are located. Before archaeological excavations began, the cave was almost entirely infilled with carstic [[detritus]] and some [[foothills|foothill]] sediments as well as large boulders from past rockfalls, giving the cave the characteristics of a [[rock shelter]]. The arduous excavation process not only revealed its important [[archaeological sequence]] but also the true nature of this cave; the cave was formed along the [[stratigraphy|stratification]] joints of the [[limestone]] levels, in a north-south direction dipping to the west, with a varied range of [[speleothem]]s typical of closed cavities with a gallery [[geomorphology|morphology]].<ref name=ERA>{{cite web|title=Pastores merinies y enterramientos de la Edad del Bronce en Bray´s Cave (Gibraltar)|url=http://blog.eracultura.com/2013/09/pastores-merinies-y-enterramientos-de-la-edad-del-bronce-en-bray%C2%B4s-cave-gibraltar/|publisher=ERA Cultura|accessdate=22 September 2013}}</ref>
==Archaeology==
===Stratigraphy=== The cave's sequence features three phases of human occupation with clearly differentiated sedimentary levels, in addition to a further two levels which are archaeologically sterile:<ref name=ERA/>
====Level I==== Period of modern-contemporary use, ranging from the 18th to 20th centuries.<ref name=ERA/>
====Level II==== Period of medieval occupation. The level has been identified, through the ceramic and [[zooarchaeology|zooarchaeological]] record, as a 14th-century [[Marinid dynasty|Marinid]] occupation of a pastoral character, whereby the occupants made use of the cave as a 'refuge' leaving behind the remains of their ceramic belongings and [[hearth]]s.<ref name=ERA/>
====Level III==== Bronze Age occupation with funerary use. It develops around [[rimstone]] formations as well as the caves floor and walls, forming an organised and hierarchical burial area.<ref name=ERA/>
===Marinid shepherds=== Founded by the [[Almohad Caliphate|Almohads]] with the construction of [[Moorish Gibraltar|Madinat al-Fath]] ({{lang-en|City of Victory}}) in the 12th century, Gibraltar was one of the strongholds of the Marinid Protectorate in the [[Iberian Peninsula]]; this is reflected in the monumental [[Moorish Castle]] with its disproportionate [[Tower of Homage]] and the baths, which can be visited today within the [[Gibraltar Museum]], as well as in other contemporary remains found during the numerous digs carried out by the Gibraltar Museum.<ref name=ERA/><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Giles Guzmán|first1=Francisco José|last2=Giles Pacheco|first2=Francisco|last3=Finlayson|first3=Clive|title=La Puerta de Granada de Gibraltar. Nuevas Aportaciones a la Arquitectura y Arqueología Islámica Gibraltareña|journal=Almoraima|year=2009|issue=39|url=http://mancomunidadcg.org/IECG/doc/revistas/26_FGILES.pdf|accessdate=23 September 2013|authorlink3=Clive Finlayson|language=Spanish}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Gutiérrez López|first1=José María|last2=Mata Almonte|first2=Esperanza|last3=Finlayson|first3=Clive|last4=Giles Pacheco|first4=Francisco|last5=Blanes Delgado|first5=Carmen|last6=Santiago Pérez|first6=Antonio|last7=Aguilera Rodríguez|first7=Luis|title=Gibraltar: Medieval Archaeology. Primeras aportaciones de un proyecto de investigación. Excavación arqueológica en el Museo de Gibraltar|journal=I Congreso Internacional Fortificaciones en al-Andalus|date=November–December 1996|url=https://www.academia.edu/3157794/Gibraltar_Medieval_Archaology._Primeras_aportaciones_de_un_proyecto_de_investigacion._Excavacion_arqueologica_en_el_Museo_de_Gibraltar|accessdate=23 September 2013|authorlink3=Clive Finlayson|language=Spanish}}</ref>
The remains at Bray's Cave are characteristic of sporadic pastoral occupations, which during the [[Middle Ages]] continued to develop in many caves. A ceramic record was discovered consisting of cooking pots and bowls, along with large amounts of goat bones, many of them young, and hearth remains.<ref name=ERA/>
===Bronze Age burials=== Given the lack of data available in southern Iberia in relation to the Bronze Age, the discoveries unearthed at Bray's Cave are of great importance. Previous findings, conducted by [[George Palao]] at [[Judge's Cave]], [[Pete's Paradise Cave]] and [[Devil's Fall Cave]], excavations carried out by non-specialists, suggested that some of the caves of Gibraltar had had a funerary use.<ref name=ERA/>
A large circular-shaped rimstone with an approximate diameter of {{convert|1.5|m}} is located towards the bottom of the cave; a significant accumulation of angular interlocked limestone clasts were documented here, constituting the closure of a burial of great archaeological interest where several secondary burials had been carried out adapting the rimstone as if it were a [[cist]] or [[niche (architecture)|niche]].<ref name=ERA/>
The burials are scattered throughout the cave, demonstrating burial areas and areas resulting from the removal of these to be reused.<ref name=ERA/>
Along with the [[paleontology|palaeontological]] remains, a ceramic record emerged consisting of common finds from this chrono-cultural period such as bowls with in-turned, straight or parabolic rims, large globular vessels and some pots. The goat and [[malacology|malacological]] remains that were documented are a reflection of the sources of nourishment of these communities.<ref name=ERA/>
The burials unearthed at Bray's Cave have added to the number of known burial sites of this period in southern Iberia, such as the ''[[:es:Necrópolis de los Algarbes|Necrópolis de los Algarbes]]'' in [[Tarifa]], ''La Loma del Puerco'' in [[Chiclana de la Frontera|Chiclana]], ''El Estanquillo'' in [[San Fernando, Cádiz|San Fernando]] and ''El Cerro del Berrueco'' in [[Medina-Sidonia]].<ref name=ERA/>
==References== {{reflist}}
{{Caves of Gibraltar}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = C. K. Gunsalus | image = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = | birth_place = | nationality = | other_names = | education = [[University of Illinois College of Law]] {{small|(1984)}}
[[University of Illinois at Urbana–Champaign]] {{small|(1978)}} | occupation =[[Director of the National Center for Professional and Research Ethics (NCPRE) at the University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign]]
[[Research Professor in the Coordinated Science Laboratory]]
[[Professor Emerita in the College of Business]] | years_active = | known_for =Expert, speaker, author and workshop presenter in the areas of conflict resolution, communication, research and organizational ethics, leadership, negotiation and professionalism | notable_works = }} '''C. K. Gunsalus''' is the Director of the National Center for Professional and Research Ethics (NCPRE) at the [[University of Illinois at Urbana–Champaign|University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign]], in addition to being a Research Professor in the [[Coordinated Science Laboratory]] and Professor Emerita in the [[UIUC College of Business|College of Business]].{{Cite web | url = https://csl.illinois.edu/directory/faculty/gunsalus | title = University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign Coordinated Science Laboratory | last = | first = | date = | website = | publisher = | access-date = 27 February 2016 }} ==Education== Gunsalus graduated Magna Cum Laude from the [[University of Illinois College of Law]] in 1984 after receiving her AB with distinction in History from the [[University of Illinois at Urbana–Champaign|University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign]] in 1978. She is licensed to practice law in the state of Illinois. ==Current research== Gunsalus is a speaker, author and workshop presenter on matters of [[research integrity]], [[leadership]], [[ethics]] and professionalism in academia. Her writing and speaking has been characterized as "lucid, practical and remarkably shrewd,"{{Cite web | url = http://www.hup.harvard.edu/catalog.php?isbn=9780674023154&content=reviews | title = Harvard University Press | last = | first = | date = | website = | publisher = | access-date = 27 February 2016 }} and she presents "an extremely useful and comprehensive set of tools and skills" in the area of academic ethics "in a conversational tone, with a good sense of humor." She is the principal investigator for a $2.7 million project collaborating on academic leadership development with [[Nanyang Technological University]] in [[Singapore]]{{Cite web |url = http://ethicscenter.csl.illinois.edu/2014/09/09/ncpre-partners-with-ntu-to-develop-new-generation-of-asian-academic-leaders/ |title = NCPRE partners with NTU to develop new generation of Asian academic leaders |last = |first = |date = |website = |publisher = |access-date = 27 February 2016 }}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} and was the PI for NCPRE’s centerpiece project, [https://web.archive.org/web/20160410015948/http://ethicscenter.csl.illinois.edu/about-us/ Ethics CORE], a national online ethics resource initiated with $1.5 million from the [[National Science Foundation]].{{Cite web | url = https://csl.illinois.edu/news/university-illinois-launches-online-ethics-resource-researchers-professionals | title = University of Illinois launches online ethics resource for researchers, professionals | last = Gudeman | first = Kim | date = 20 September 2012 | website = | publisher = Coordinated Science Laboratory | access-date = 27 February 2016 }} Gunsalus has collaborated with Carol Thrush, Brian Martinson and other authorities to develop the SOuRCe,{{Cite web |url = http://ethicscenter.csl.illinois.edu/sorc/ |title = Survey of Organizational Research Climate (SOuRCe) |last = |first = |date = |website = |publisher = |access-date = 27 February 2016 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20160314190430/http://ethicscenter.csl.illinois.edu/sorc/# |archive-date = 2016-03-14 |dead-url = yes |df = }} the only validated instrument for evaluating research climate in organizations.{{Cite web |url = http://jre.sagepub.com/content/early/2014/09/29/1556264614552798.refs |title = Journal of Empirical Research on Human Research Ethics |last = |first = |date = |website = |publisher = |access-date = 27 February 2016 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20160808080028/http://jre.sagepub.com/content/early/2014/09/29/1556264614552798.refs# |archive-date = 2016-08-08 |dead-url = yes |df = }} The growing dataset permits participants to compare their own environments to others both inside and outside their own institutions. Findings from use of the SOuRCe informed an April 2015 [[Nature (journal)|Nature]] article on the effects of research climate on desirable and undesirable research behaviors.{{Cite web | url = http://www.nature.com/naturejobs/science/articles/10.1038/nj7549-713a | title = Workplace climate: Metrics for ethics | last = Baker | first = Monya | date = 29 April 2015 | website = Nature.com | publisher = | access-date = 27 February 2016 }} Her areas of professional interest include [[research]] and organizational integrity, [[leadership]], professionalism, [[negotiation]], [[conflict resolution]] and [[communication]]. ==Career== During her tenure at Illinois, Gunsalus has held appointments and taught courses in the Colleges of [[University of Illinois College of Law|Law]], [[University of Illinois College of Medicine|Medicine]], [[UIUC College of Business|Business]] and [[UIUC College of Engineering|Engineering]], and served as assistant and associate vice chancellor for research from 1984-1994, associate provost from 1994-2002, associate dean of the [[UIUC College of Liberal Arts and Sciences|College of Liberal Arts and Sciences]] from 2002-2010, as well as acting as special counsel in the [http://www.legal.uillinois.edu/ Office of University Counsel] and as the campus research standards (integrity) officer. She started her career at the [[Computer-based Education Research Laboratory]], which developed the [[PLATO (computer system)|PLATO]] project. ==Membership and honors== Gunsalus is currently a member of the [[National Academy of Sciences|National Academy of Sciences Committee on Responsible Science]].{{Cite web | url = http://www8.nationalacademies.org/cp/committeeview.aspx?key=49387 | title = National Academy of Sciences, Engineering and Medicine | last = | first = | date = | website = | publisher = | access-date = 27 February 2016 }} She chaired the [[American Association for the Advancement of Science]] (AAAS) Committee on Scientific Freedom and Responsibility and, later, the AAAS Scientific Freedom and Responsibility Award committee.{{Cite web | url = http://www.aaas.org/event/workshop-responsible-professional-practices | title = Workshop on Responsible Professional Practices | last = | first = | date = | website = American Association for the Advancement of Science | publisher = | access-date = 27 February 2016 }} She has served on the AAAS Council of Delegates, the Illinois Supreme Court Commission on Professionalism,{{Cite web | url = http://www.2civility.org/about/commissioners/ | title = Commissioners of the Illinois Supreme Court Commission on Professionalism | last = | first = | date = | website = | publisher = Illinois Supreme Court Commission on Professionalism | access-date = 27 February 2016 }} and the United States Commission on Research Integrity.{{Cite web | url = http://ori.hhs.gov/sites/default/files/report_commission.pdf | title = Integrity and Misconduct in Research: Report of the Commission on Research Integrity | last = | first = | date = 1995 | website = | publisher = Commission on Research Integrity | access-date = 27 February 2016 }} In 2013, she was selected as one of 15 finalists (out of 222 nominations) for the [[Economist Intelligence Unit|Economist Intelligence Unit’s]] Best Business Professor of the Year Award.{{Cite web | url = https://news.illinois.edu/ii/13/0321/ach.html | title = Inside Illinois Achievements | last = | first = | date = 21 March 2013 | website = | publisher = | access-date = 27 February 2016 }} She is an elected fellow of the American Association for the Advancement of Science in recognition of her "sustained contributions to the national debate over improving the practical handling of ethical, legal, professional and administrative issues as they affect scientific research."{{Cite web |url = http://csl.illinois.edu/news/gunsalus-elected-delegate-aaas%E2%80%99-societal-impacts-science-and-engineering-council |title = Gunsalus elected delegate to AAAS’ Societal Impacts of Science and Engineering Council |last = Dahlquist |first = April |date = 22 March 2011 |website = Coordinated Science Laboratory |publisher = |access-date = 27 February 2016 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20161220180825/http://csl.illinois.edu/news/gunsalus-elected-delegate-aaas%E2%80%99-societal-impacts-science-and-engineering-council# |archive-date = 2016-12-20 |dead-url = yes |df = }} ==Selected publications== * Guest Editorial: Penalty Too Light. The Cancer Letter. November 13, 2015 [http://www.cancerletter.com/articles/20151113_2] * Gunsalus: Duke’s 4.5 Years is at the Extreme End of the Spectrum For a Misconduct Probe. The Cancer Letter, May 8, 2015 [http://www.cancerletter.com/articles/20150508_5 ] *Rennie, Drummond, and C. Kristina Gunsalus. [https://business.illinois.edu/gunsalus/gunsalus_pdf/9_Scientific%20Misconduct%20New%20Definition,%20Procedures%20and%20Office%20Perhaps%20a%20New%20Leaf.pdf "Scientific misconduct: New definition, procedures, and office—perhaps a new leaf."] JAMA 269.7 (1993): 915-917. * Misconduct Expert Dissects Duke Scandal. The Cancer Letter, January 23, 2015. [http://www.cancerletter.com/articles/20150123_3] * Gunsalus, C. K., et al. [https://business.illinois.edu/gunsalus/gunsalus_pdf/35_Mission%20Creep%20in%20the%20IRB%20World.pdf "Mission creep in the IRB world."] (2006). * [http://www.hup.harvard.edu/catalog.php?isbn=9780674049444 The Young Professional's Survival Guide: From Cab Fares to Moral Snares]. Cambridge, Mass: Harvard University Press, 2012 {{ISBN|9780674049444}} *Gunsalus, C. Kristina, et al. [http://poseidon01.ssrn.com/delivery.php?ID=530112070066073010095015074105067022009056033020093009075020093091005077125006118023004010006016122030040078027098014120123006004002018054070126085065078029086063075007091066101065005016087121091010089117105116004098072114112091024115123095089123&EXT=pdf "The Illinois White Paper Improving the System for Protecting Human Subjects: Counteracting IRB "Mission Creep"."] Qualitative Inquiry 13.5 (2007): 617-649. * [http://www.hup.harvard.edu/catalog.php?isbn=9780674023154 The College Administrator's Survival Guide]. Cambridge, Mass: Harvard University Press, 2006. {{ISBN|9780674023154}} * "How to blow the whistle and still have a career afterwards." Science and Engineering Ethics 4.1 (1998): 51-64.[http://www.business.illinois.edu/gunsalus/gunsalus_pdf/19_How%20to%20Blow%20the%20Whistle%20and%20Still%20Have%20a%20Career%20Afterwards.pdf PDF] * "Preventing the need for whistleblowing: Practical advice for university administrators." Science and Engineering Ethics 4.1 (1998): 75-94. [https://business.illinois.edu/gunsalus/gunsalus_pdf/20_Preventing%20the%20Need%20for%20Whistleblowing%20--%20Practical%20Advice%20for%20University%20Administrators.pdf PDF] == References == {{Reflist}} ==Further reading== * https://www.insidehighered.com/users/ck-gunsalus * http://blogs.scientificamerican.com/doing-good-science/c-k-gunsalus-on-responsible-and-prudent-whistleblowing/ * http://www.scientificamerican.com/article/stimulus-funds-science-misconduct/ * http://blogs.scientificamerican.com/doing-good-science/how-we-decide-to-falsify/ * http://www.nature.com/news/2010/100817/full/news.2010.414.html * http://www.nature.com/news/2008/080722/full/454379a.html * https://www.nsf.gov/news/news_summ.jsp?cntn_id=118057 * http://college.usatoday.com/2012/11/03/new-book-helps-young-professionals-navigate-workplace-ethics/ * http://www.csmonitor.com/Books/2012/1112/6-tips-for-new-workers-from-The-Young-Professional-s-Survival-Guide/Choosing-between-jobs * http://retractionwatch.com/2015/06/18/if-you-think-its-rude-to-ask-to-look-at-your-co-authors-data-youre-not-doing-science-guest-post/ == External links == * [http://ethicscenter.csl.illinois.edu/ National Center for Professional and Research Ethics (NCPRE) Website] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20160314190430/http://ethicscenter.csl.illinois.edu/sorc/ SOURCE] * [http://www.gunsalus.net/ C. revision.text:
{{Infobox Musical | name = Cabin in the Sky | image = Cabin in the Sky (musical) cover.jpg | music = Vernon Duke | lyrics = John Latouche | book = Lynn Root | basis = | productions = 1940 [[Al Hirschfeld Theatre|Martin Beck Theatre]]
<!-- Please do not include production-specific (acting, directing, etc.) awards --> | awards = }}
'''''Cabin in the Sky''''' is a [[Musical theater|musical]] with music by [[Vernon Duke]], [[Musical theatre#Introduction and definitions|book]] by Lynn Root, and lyrics by [[John La Touche (lyricist)|John Latouche]]. The musical opened on [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] in 1940.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|title = Cabin in the Sky {{!}} IBDB: The official source for Broadway Information|url = http://www.ibdb.com/Production/View/1025|website = www.ibdb.com|accessdate = 2015-10-23}}</ref> The show is described as a "parable of Southern Negro Life with echoes of [[Ferenc Molnár]]'s ''[[Liliom]]'' (which would be turned into the musical ''[[Carousel (musical)|Carousel]]'') and [[Marc Connelly]]'s ''[[The Green Pastures]]''."<ref>{{Cite book|title = Broadway Musicals: Show By Show|last = Green|first = Stanley|publisher = Applause Theatre & Cinema Books|year = 2011|isbn = 978-1-55783-784-4|location = Milwaukee|pages = 111}}</ref>
==History==
Lynn Root wrote the libretto and brought it to [[George Balanchine]], "who was anxious to do it as his first assignment as director of an entire Broadway production."<ref name=":1">{{cite book |title=The World of Musical Comedy |last=Green |first=Stanley |publisher=Da Capo Press |year=1980 |isbn=0-306-80207-4 |location=San Diego |pages=176}}</ref> Balanchine took the script to [[Vernon Duke]] to compose the music. "On reading the script, my first impulse was to turn it down because as much as I admired the [[Black people|Negro]] race and its musical gifts, I didn't think myself sufficiently attuned to Negro folklore."<ref name=":2">{{cite book |title=Passport to Paris |last=Duke |first=Vernon |publisher=Little, Brown, and Company |year=1955 |isbn= |location=Boston |pages=384–389}}</ref> However, Duke ended up taking up the project but insisted on "a lyricist with some direct contact with Southern Negroes."<ref name=":1" /> Duke talked to [[Ira Gershwin]] and [[Yip Harburg|E.Y. Harburg]] but they both turned it down. (Gershwin was working on ''[[Lady in the Dark]]'' and Harburg thought the composer was "incapable of writing the kind of score the play required.<ref name=":1" />)
Duke ended up picking [[John La Touche (lyricist)|John Latouche]] as his lyricist and the two began work in [[Virginia Beach, Virginia|Virginia Beach]].<ref name=":3">{{cite web |url=http://drum.lib.umd.edu/bitstream/handle/1903/8604/umi-umd-5714.pdf |title=Beyond Racial Stereotypes: Subversive Subtexts in Cabin in the Sky |date=2008 |accessdate=2015-10-23 |website=Digital Repository of the University of Maryland |publisher=University of Maryland |last=Weber |first=Kate Marie}}</ref> The two wanted to absorb aspects of the local Black culture but "decided to stay away from pedantic authenticity and write our own kind of 'colored' songs."<ref name=":2" />
The rehearsals for the show were rather interesting between the Russian trio (Duke, Balanchine and [[Boris Aronson]] - the designer) and the all-black cast. In his book ''Passport to Paris'', Duke quotes George Ross' description from the ''Telegram:'' "Pit a threesome of turbulent Russians against a tempestuous cast of Negro players from Harlem and what have you got? Well, in this instance the result is a lingual ruckus approaching bedlam. At least half a dozen times at the rehearsal of ''Cabin in the Sky'', [[Ethel Waters]], [[Todd Duncan]], [[Rex Ingram (actor)|Rex Ingram]], [[J. Rosamond Johnson]], [[Katherine Dunham]] and her dancers have paused in puzzlement while the argumentative trio of [[Moscow|Muscovites]] disputed a difference of opinion in their native tongue. The Russian vowels and consonants fly as thick as borsht. After ten minutes of such alien harangue and retort, Miss Waters asks what it is all about. ‘George,’ Duke generally interprets, ‘just said the answer is yes!' and then rehearsals are resumed under the flag of truce until the next vocal flare-up."<ref name=":2" />
Three days before the opening, Duke decided to replace the song "We'll Live All Over Again" after Waters expressed dissatisfaction with it. It was replaced with the showstopper "Taking a Chance on Love."<ref name=":3" /> The song was originally "Foolin' Around with Love" which he wrote with [[Ted Fetter]]. Latouche retitled it and wrote the reprises.<ref name=":1" />
[[J. Rosamond Johnson]], besides taking a small role, trained the singing chorus. [[Katherine Dunham]] led her dancers through their slithering paces, assisted in the choreography by George Balanchine.<ref name=":4">{{cite book |title=American Musical Theatre: A Chronicle |last=Bordman |first=Gerald |publisher=Oxford University Press |year=1992 |isbn=0-19-507242-1 |location=New York |pages=521–522}}</ref>
==Productions== The musical premiered on Broadway at the [[Martin Beck Theatre]] on October 25, 1940 and closed on March 8, 1941 after 156 performances. The musical is based on the story ''Little Joe'' by Lynn Root.
Musicals Tonight! presented a staged concert of the musical at the 14th Street YMHA, New York City in October 2003.<ref>[[Simonson, Robert]] and Jones, Kenneth. [http://www.playbill.com/news/article/musicals-tonight-takes-a-chance-on-cabin-in-the-sky-115829# "Musicals Tonight! Takes a Chance on 'Cabin in the Sky'"] playbill.com, October 21, 2003</ref><ref>[http://www.musicalstonight.org/REVcabininsky.html "'Cabin in the Sky' Reviews"] musicalstonight.org, October 21, 2003, accessed December 12, 2015</ref>
The musical was presented in a staged concert by [[Encores!]] in February 2016, starring [[Chuck Cooper (actor)|Chuck Cooper]], [[Norm Lewis]], and [[LaChanze]].<ref>Hetrick, Adam. [http://www.playbill.com/news/article/chuck-cooper-lachanze-norm-lewis-will-star-in-encores-cabin-in-the-sky-374484# "Chuck Cooper, LaChanze, Norm Lewis Will Star in Encores! 'Cabin in the Sky'"] playbill.com, December 7, 2015</ref>
==Musical numbers== Source: Internet Broadway Database<ref name=":0" />
'''ACT 1:''' * "The General's Song" - Lawd's General and Saints * "Pay Heed" - Lawd's General and Saints * "Taking a Chance on Love" - Petunia * "Cabin in the Sky" - Petunia and Little Joe * "Holy Unto the Lord" - Petunia, Little Joe, Brother Green, and Churchmembers * "Dem Bones" - Petunia, J. Rosamond Johnson Singer, and Churchmembers * "Do What You Wanna Do" - Lucifier Jr and Imps * "Taking a Chance on Love (reprise)" - Petunia and Little Joe
'''ACT 2:''' * "Fugue" - Lawd's General and Saints * "My Old Virginia Home on the Nile" - Petunia and Little Joe * "Egyptian Ballet" - The Dunham Dancers * "It's Not So Good To Be Bad" - Lawd's General * "Love Me Tomorrow" - Georgia Brown and Little Joe * "Love Turned the Light Out" - Petunia * "Lazy Steps" - The Dunham Dancers * "Boogy Woogy" - The Dunham Dancers * "Honey in the Honeycomb" - Georgia Brown and Boys * "Savannah" - Petunia
==Characters and original cast== The original Broadway characters and cast:<ref name=":0" /> {| class="wikitable" style="width:1000;" |- ! Character ! Broadway (1940) |- ! Petunia |colspan='1' align=center|[[Ethel Waters]] |- ! Little Joe |colspan='1' align=center|[[Dooley Wilson]] |- ! Lucifer Junior |colspan='1' align=center|[[Rex Ingram (actor)|Rex Ingram]] |- ! Georgia Brown |colspan='1' align=center|[[Katherine Dunham]] |- ! Lawd's General |colspan='1' align=center|[[Todd Duncan]] |- ! Fleetfoot |colspan='1' align=center|Milton Williams |- ! Dr. Jones |colspan='1' align=center|Louis Sharp |- ! John Henry |colspan='1' align=center|J. Louis Johnson |- ! Lily |colspan='1' align=center|Georgia Burke |- ! Domino Johnson |colspan='1' align=center|Dick Campbell |- !Imps |Jieno Moxzer Harris |- ! Brother Green |colspan='1' align=center|J. Rosamond Johnson |}
==Critical reception== The musical was very well received. [[Gerald Bordman]] wrote "Wisely, everyone involved in the show rejected the easy excesses and crassness so many musicals resorted to. Certainly they avoided turning the evening into a black minstrel show. Throughout the production a tasteful restraint, a sense of what as appropriate to the story, was maintained. This rare display of integrity made ''Cabin in the Sky'' an attractive enough evening to keep ticket buyers coming for 20 weeks."<ref name=":4" />
Thomas S. Hischak wrote, "With enthusiastic reviews, an outstanding score, and a powerhouse cast of some of the finest African Americans in the business, it was surprising the musical did not run longer than twenty weeks."<ref>{{Cite book|title = Broadway Plays and Musicals|last = Hischak|first = Thomas|publisher = McFarland & Company, Inc|year = 2009|isbn = 978-0-7864-9754-6|location = Jefferson, North Carolina|pages = 64}}</ref>
However, not everyone liked the show. Critic Richard Watts, Jr. wrote in his review that the show was "merely a white man's self-conscious attempt to write a pseudo-folk fable of another race."<ref>{{Cite web|title = The Pittsburgh Press - Google News Archive Search|url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1144&dat=19401103&id=844cAAAAIBAJ&sjid=i44EAAAAIBAJ&pg=3560,4051209&hl=en|website = news.google.com|accessdate = 2015-10-24}}</ref>
''Cabin in the Sky'' proved to be the last major success of Duke's career.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Broadway: Its History, People, and Places|last = Bloom|first = Ken|publisher = Routledge|year = 2004|isbn = 0-4159-3704-3|location = New York|pages = 137}}</ref>
The show was made into the 1943 film ''[[Cabin in the Sky (film)|Cabin in the Sky]]'', but as Denny Flinn stated in his book, "It is noble that Hollywood made a black musical at all, but there are too many interpolations to the John Latouche-Vernon Duke score."<ref>{{Cite book|title = Musical! A Grand Tour|last = Flinn|first = Denny|publisher = Schirmer Books|year = 1997|isbn = 0-02-864610-X|location = New York|pages = 504}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.playbillvault.com/Show/Detail/8315/Cabin-in-the-Sky "'Cabin in the Sky' at PlaybillVault.com] *[https://memory.loc.gov/diglib/ihas/html/dunham/dunham-notes-cabininthesky.html "Notes on 'Cabin in the Sky', Katherine Dunham Collection"]

revision.text:
The '''CrustaStun''' is a device designed to administer a lethal electric shock to [[shellfish]] (such as [[lobsters]], [[crabs]], and [[crayfish]]) before cooking. This avoids boiling a live shellfish which may be able to experience pain in a way similar to vertebrates. The CrustaStun comprises a stainless-steel box approximately the size of a domestic [[microwave oven]] containing a tray with a wet sponge and an electrode<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.maxindustrialmicrowave.com|title=How to use Domestic Microwave Oven for CrustaStun|publisher=About.com|accessdate=July 22, 2013|date=December 16, 2010}}</ref>. The shellfish is placed in the box and when the lid is closed, the wet sponge conducts the current which electrocutes the animal with a 110 [[volt]], 2–5 [[Ampere|amp]] charge. It is reported the CrustaStun renders the shellfish unconscious in 0.3 seconds and kills the animal in 5 to 10 seconds, compared to 3 minutes to kill a lobster by boiling or 4.5 minutes for a crab.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/food-and-drink/news/ill-have-my-lobster-electrocuted-please-1824925.html|title=I'll have my lobster electrocuted, please|author=McSmith, A.|publisher=The Independent (Newspaper)|accessdate=June 14, 2013|location=London|date=November 21, 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sciencetech/article-1324142/CrustaStun-The-humane-gadget-kills-lobsters-single-jolt-electricity.html|title=CrustaStun: The 'humane' gadget that kills lobsters with a single jolt of electricity|author=Anon.|publisher=MailOnline (Newspaper)|accessdate=June 14, 2013|location=London|date=October 27, 2010}}</ref>
The inventor of the device, Simon Buckhaven, worked for two years with scientists from the [[University of Bristol]] to develop the device which is manufactured by a company in [[England]], at an estimated cost of £2,500 (in 2009).
There are claims that shellfish killed with the CrustaStun taste better than those killed by boiling. [[Waitrose]], [[Tesco]] and other major supermarkets in the United Kingdom have insisted that all shellfish products supplied to them are killed using this method.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.selectiveseafoods.com/crustastun.htm|title=Selective Seafoods; Freshly Prepared Crabs,Lobsters and other Locally Produced Seafoods.|author1=Griffiths, G.|author2=White, M.|accessdate=June 14, 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130620115030/http://www.selectiveseafoods.com/crustastun.htm|archivedate=June 20, 2013|df=}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Pain in crustaceans]]
==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}}
==Further reading== *[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/4097798.stm BBC article on the device and its inventor]
==External links== *[http://www.crustastun.com/ Homepage for the device]

{{EngvarB|date=June 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2017}} {{Infobox musical artist |name = DJ Derek |image = DJ Derek cropped.jpg |caption = DJ Derek in 2007 |birth_name = Derek Serpell-Morris |birth_date = {{Birth date|df=yes|1941|12|18}} |birth_place = [[Bristol]], England |death_date = c. July 2015 (aged 73) |background = non_performing_personnel |genre = {{hlist|[[Rocksteady]]|[[reggae]]|[[ska]]|[[dancehall]]|[[soul music|soul]]}} |years_active = 1977–2013 }}
'''DJ Derek''', born '''Derek Serpell-Morris''' (18 December 1941 – July 2015)<ref name="factmag">{{cite web|last1=Fact|title=DJ Derek announces retirement, confirms last ever show|url=http://www.factmag.com/2013/07/10/dj-derek-announces-retirement-confirms-last-ever-show/|accessdate=22 April 2016}}</ref> was an English DJ based in [[Bristol]]. In a DJ career that spanned over 40 years, he was known for playing a blend of 60s [[rocksteady]], [[reggae]], [[ska]], [[dancehall]] and [[soul music|soul]]. He was reported missing in July 2015 and his remains were found on 10 March 2016.
==Early life== He was born in Bristol, the second son of a carpenter,<ref>{{cite news|last1=Lynskey|first1=Dorian|title=The life and death of DJ Derek, an unlikely reggae legend|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/mar/23/dj-derek-life-death-unlikely-reggae-legend-bristol|accessdate=24 March 2016|work=The Guardian|date=23 March 2016}}</ref> and raised close to St Andrew's Park, off [[Gloucester Road, Bristol|Gloucester Road]]. Derek was a [[washboard (musical instrument)|washboard]] player in a [[skiffle]] group in 1956 and later a drummer in a [[rock and roll]] band, after which he spent 10–18 years working in the accounts department of the confectionery firm [[J. S. Fry & Sons]], later part of [[Cadbury]].<ref name="post">{{cite web | url=http://www.bristolpost.co.uk/Meet-DJ-Derek/story-11237186-detail/story.html | title=Meet DJ Derek | work=Bristol Evening Post | date=7 February 2009 | accessdate=17 August 2015 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150923230632/http://www.bristolpost.co.uk/Meet-DJ-Derek/story-11237186-detail/story.html | archivedate=23 September 2015 | df=dmy-all }}</ref>
==DJ career== [[File:DJ Derek at Into The Great Wide Open.jpg|thumb|left|DJ Derek at into The Great Wide Open, September 2009]] Following his second divorce and resignation from his accountancy job in 1977, Derek began his DJ career "by accident" in his mid-30s, as a reggae DJ at the Star and Garter [[pub]] in [[Montpelier, Bristol|Montpelier]] an inner city area of Bristol.<ref name ="post"/><ref name="BBC">{{cite web | url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/insideout/west/series9/week_seven.shtml | title=The legendary DJ Derek | work=Inside Out – West | publisher=BBC | date=20 February 2006 | accessdate=13 August 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.independent.ie/world-news/europe/niece-launches-social-media-campaign-as-wellknown-dj-goes-missing-31400886.html | title=Niece launches social media campaign as well-known DJ goes missing | publisher=[[Irish Independent]] | date=24 July 2015 | accessdate=30 August 2015}}</ref> He moved to the adjacent [[St Pauls, Bristol|St Pauls]] area in 1978.<ref name = "BBC3"/> DJ Derek became a well known regular and respected feature in Bristol's music scene, referred to as a "legend" by many sources including the city's elected mayor [[George Ferguson (Mayor of Bristol)|George Ferguson]]. He was nicknamed "Britain's oldest DJ".<ref name= "Indie">{{cite web | url=https://www.independent.co.uk/incoming/pop--dj-derek-and-the-dominoes-1439857.html | title=POP / DJ Derek and the dominoes | work= [[The Independent]] | date=18 November 1994 | accessdate=11 August 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2015/jul/24/dj-derek-britains-oldest-dj-goes-missing | title=DJ Derek – 'Britain's oldest DJ' – missing | work=[[The Guardian]] | date=24 July 2015 | accessdate=16 August 2015}}</ref><ref name = "BBCDerek">{{cite web | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-bristol-33648110 | title=DJ Derek: Police hunt for missing 73-year-old Bristol man | publisher=BBC News | date=24 July 2015 | accessdate=11 August 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.itv.com/news/west/update/2015-08-12/police-say-sighting-of-dj-derek-in-yate-is-credible/ | title=Bristol club night will help fund the search for missing DJ Derek | publisher=itv.com | date=12 August 2015 | accessdate=13 August 2015}}</ref> In 2012 he received the Bristol [[Lord Mayor]]'s medal for an "outstanding" contribution to music in the city.<ref name = "BBCDerek"/> Speaking to [[BBC Radio 4]], he said he finished most sets with the [[Bob Marley]] hit "[[One Love/People Get Ready|One Love]]", saying "It's a perfect signing-off record for a reggae set—let's get together and feel all right. So next time, people, let's get together and feel all right."<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.nme.com/news/dj-derek/87343 | title=Police confirm reported sightings of missing DJ Derek | work=[[NME]] | date=4 August 2015 | accessdate=16 August 2015}}</ref> He [[Master of Ceremonies|MC]]ed in [[Jamaican Patois]] while DJing.<ref name = "BBC"/><ref name= "Indie"/>
Derek played DJ sets at many major music festivals, including [[Glastonbury Festival|Glastonbury]] and [[The Big Chill (music festival)|The Big Chill]], and places like [[Las Palmas]] ([[Gran Canaria]]); as well as regular DJ sets in London and across the UK.<ref name = "BBC"/><ref name = "BBC3"/> In June 2006 he released a compilation of his favourite tracks titled ''DJ Derek Presents Sweet Memory Sounds'', through [[Trojan Records]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/sweet-memory-sounds-mw0000408167 | title=DJ Derek Sweet Memory Sounds | publisher=AllMusic | accessdate=11 August 2015}}</ref> He appeared in [[Dizzee Rascal]]'s video for "[[Dirtee Disco]]".<ref name=bbc3/> In 2013 he played his final set before retiring at [[Notting Hill Arts Club]] in London on New Year's Eve, though he later played a one-off show in December 2014.<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.bristolpost.co.uk/DJ-Derek-spins-discs-final-time-Bristol/story-20379606-detail/story.html |title= DJ Derek spins his discs for final time in Bristol |date= 31 December 2013 |accessdate= 29 July 2015 |work= Bristol Post |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20150923224554/http://www.bristolpost.co.uk/DJ-Derek-spins-discs-final-time-Bristol/story-20379606-detail/story.html |archivedate= 23 September 2015 |df= dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url= https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2016/mar/11/human-remains-found-in-woodland-near-bristol-believed-to-be-dj-derek |title= Human remains found in woodland near Bristol believed to be 'DJ Derek' |date= 11 March 2016 |accessdate= 16 March 2016 |author= Jamie Grierson |work= The Guardian}}</ref> He had a passion for travelling long distances by bus to visit newly opened [[Wetherspoons|Wetherspoon pubs]] .<ref name = "BBC3">{{cite web | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-bristol-33866741 | title=Missing DJ Derek: Police make national appeal | publisher=BBC News | date=12 August 2015 | accessdate=13 August 2015}}</ref><ref name="IOW">{{cite web | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/iplayer/episode/b068xx77/inside-out-west-07092015 | title=Inside Out West | publisher=BBC | date=7 September 2015 | accessdate=8 September 2015}}</ref>
==Disappearance== In July 2015 Derek's family announced that he had been missing for three weeks, appealing for information related to his whereabouts.<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.itv.com/news/west/update/2015-07-24/bristols-dj-derek-missing-for-three-weeks/ |title= Bristol's DJ Derek missing for three weeks |date= 24 July 2015 |accessdate= 24 July 2015 |publisher=ITV}}</ref> Police confirmed that he had not used his bank account since the beginning of July, and could not have gone abroad as he has no passport.<ref name=bbc3>{{cite web |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-bristol-33699598 |title= DJ Derek: Family and friends to search Bristol for missing 73-year-old |date= 29 July 2015 |accessdate= 29 July 2015 |publisher= BBC News}}</ref> He was last seen leaving the Criterion pub in St Pauls shortly after midnight on 11 July; later that morning his [[bus pass]] was used on a bus to [[Thornbury, Gloucestershire|Thornbury]], 12 miles north of Bristol.<ref>{{cite news |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-bristol-33734035 |title= DJ Derek search: Further CCTV footage tracks journey |date= 31 July 2015 |accessdate= 2 August 2015 |publisher= BBC News}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.itv.com/news/west/story/2015-08-14/leaflet-campaign-in-search-for-missing-dj-derek/ | title=Leaflet campaign in search for missing DJ Derek | publisher=itv.com | date=14 August 2015 | accessdate=15 August 2015}}</ref><ref name="IOW"/><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.westerndailypress.co.uk/Family-s-frustration-failure-DJ-Derek-Bristol/story-27948682-detail/story.html | title=Missing DJ Derek's family's frustration at failure to find Bristol legend | publisher=Western Daily Press | date=9 October 2015 | accessdate=14 October 2015 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151013010105/http://www.westerndailypress.co.uk/Family-s-frustration-failure-DJ-Derek-Bristol/story-27948682-detail/story.html | archivedate=13 October 2015 | df=dmy-all }}</ref> [[Daddy G (English musician)|Daddy G]] of [[Massive Attack]], who described Derek as a "walking musical encyclopedia", played a club night in Bristol to raise funds for a search.<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.itv.com/news/west/update/2015-08-06/member-of-massive-attack-to-play-set-at-dj-derek-fundraiser/ |title= Member of Massive Attack to play set at DJ Derek fundraiser|publisher= ITV |date= 6 August 2015 |accessdate= 8 August 2015}}</ref>
In December 2015, Derek's family said that a man matching his description had been seen fleeing a pub in Thornbury following an altercation; [[Avon and Somerset Police]] said that their investigations into his disappearance were continuing.<ref>{{cite news |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-bristol-35129963 |title= Missing DJ Derek 'was seen being chased from pub'|publisher= BBC News |date= 18 December 2015 |accessdate= 19 December 2015}}</ref> Later in December, an image taken in London of a man resembling Derek was publicised. While his family noted an "uncanny" resemblance,<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-bristol-35172033 |title= DJ Derek disappearance: Photograph 'is of him' |publisher= BBC News |date= 23 December 2015 |accessdate= 24 December 2015}}</ref> Avon and Somerset Police later announced that they had located and spoken to the man photographed, and confirmed that he was not Derek.<ref>DJ Derek disappearance: Police confirm photo is not him (28 December 2015). [https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-england-bristol-35190344 BBC.com archive]. Retrieved 30 December 2015.</ref> Derek's family began an application for [[Declared death in absentia|presumed death]] in March 2016.<ref>{{cite news |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-bristol-35717993 |title= Missing DJ Derek's family 'was sent online abuse' |date= 4 March 2016 |accessdate= 4 March 2016 |publisher= BBC News}}</ref>
On 10 March 2016, human remains were found in [[undergrowth]] near The Mall, [[Cribbs Causeway]], Bristol,<ref>{{cite web|title=Human remains 'probably missing DJ Derek'|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-bristol-35781898|publisher=BBC|accessdate=11 March 2016}}</ref><ref>[http://www.bristolpost.co.uk/Family-DJ-Derek-make-public-tribute-body/story-28909927-detail/story.html Bristol Post]{{dead link|date=November 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> and on 16 March were confirmed to be those of DJ Derek.<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-bristol-35823444 |title= DJ Derek: Tests confirm remains belong to pensioner |date= 16 March 2016 |accessdate= 16 March 2016 |publisher= BBC News}}</ref> Shortly after his remains were discovered, Bristol police said they were not treating his death as suspicious.<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.bristolpost.co.uk/Death-DJ-Derek-suspicious-police-calls-search/story-28918645-detail/story.html |title= Death of DJ Derek 'not suspicious' as police call off search |author= Michael Yong |work= Bristol Post |date= 14 March 2016 |accessdate= 16 March 2016 }}{{dead link|date=November 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref><ref>Lynskey, Dorian [https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/mar/23/dj-derek-life-death-unlikely-reggae-legend-bristol The life and death of DJ Derek, an unlikely reggae legend] ''The Guardian''. 24 March 2016</ref>
==Tributes== During the [[BBC Radio 6 Music|6 Music]] festival hosted by the BBC in Bristol in February 2016, [[Don Letts]] and [[Daddy G]] premiered a snippet of a documentary they had been working on before his disappearance. Letts said they planned to complete the film as a mark of respect, as they had halted further production until his whereabouts were revealed.<ref>[http://www.bristolpost.co.uk/6-Music-Festival-DJ-Don-Letts-pays-tribute-DJ/story-28717704-detail/story.html Craig Jones, "6 Music Festival DJ Don Letts pays tribute to DJ Derek's Bristol influence", ''Bristol Post'', 12 February 2016]{{dead link|date=November 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}. Retrieved 6 April 2016</ref> In March 2016, Bristol pub The Farm in [[St Werburghs]], one of Derek's regular haunts, revealed they were hosting an auction to raise funds for a mural near his home. On 1 April, contributions from [[Banksy]], [[Fatboy Slim]], [[Stanley Donwood]] and other local artists helped to raise over £5000 towards the fund. Mayor [[George Ferguson (Mayor of Bristol)|George Ferguson]] revealed plans for a city tribute to him, with an official announcement to follow.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Churchill|first1=L.|title=Life-size bronze statue of DJ Derek being planned for Bristol|url=http://www.bristolpost.co.uk/life-size-bronze-statue-dj-derek-planned-bristol/story-29172486-detail/story.html|accessdate=9 September 2016|work=Bristol Post|date=25 April 2016}}{{dead link|date=November 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>

{{Multiple issues| {{unreliable sources|date=February 2018}} {{more citations needed|date=January 2016}}}} {{Infobox writer <!-- for more information see [[:Template:Infobox writer/doc]] --> | name = Dave Walker | image = | caption = Dave Walker, Bangkok 1991 | pseudonym = | birth_name = | birth_date = April 7, 1955 | birth_place = [[Edmonton]], [[Alberta]] | death_date = February 14, 2014 | death_place = | occupation = [[Author]], [[photo-journalist]], [[filmmaker]] | nationality = Canadian | ethnicity = | citizenship = | education = [[Master of Arts|M.A.]] in Augmented Reality | alma_mater = [[York University, Toronto]] | period = | genre = [[journalism]], [[non-fiction]] | subject = [[Cambodia]], [[Thailand]] | movement = | notableworks = ''Hello My Big Big Honey!: Love Letters To Bangkok Bar Girls And Their Interviews'' (1998) | spouse = | partner = | signature = | website = {{URL|www.davewalkercase.com}} | portaldisp = y }} '''Dave Walker''' was a Canadian writer, filmmaker and photo-journalist who died under mysterious circumstances in 2014 in [[Cambodia]].<ref name=globe> {{cite news | url = https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/will-no-one-seek-answers-about-a-canadians-death-in-thejungle/article26328683/ | title = Why a Canadian's death in the jungle is likely to remain a mystery | work = [[Globe and Mail]] | author = Leah McLaren | date = 2015-09-11 | accessdate = 2018-11-05 | deadurl = No | quote = As for Dave Walker, friends and family around the world tried to keep the case alive, and a Toronto-based criminal historian and blogger named Peter Vronsky – a close friend of Mr. Walker since the early 1990s – continues to compile an exhaustive account of his death and the subsequent investigation. }} </ref><ref>[http://www.cbc.ca/news/world/canadian-filmmaker-dave-walker-found-dead-in-cambodia-1.2628105 CBC News: Canadian filmmaker Dave Walker found dead in Cambodia] (accessed 30 January 2016)</ref><ref>[http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2617772/Body-former-British-Army-soldier-near-Cambodian-temples-Gate-Death-ten-weeks-went-missing-family-suspects-murdered.html Daily Mail: Body of former British Army soldier found near Cambodian temple's 'Gate of Death' ten weeks after he went missing - and his family suspects he was murdered] (accessed 30 January 2016)</ref>
==Biography== Dave Walker was born in Edmonton Canada, April 7, 1955.{{citation needed|date=February 2018}}
After graduating high school, Walker served briefly as a Toronto Police constable and later joined the British Army serving in Belfast, Northern Ireland during '[[The Troubles]]' where he saw combat against the Provisional IRA ([[PIRA]]) in an urban reconnaissance unit trained by and seconded to the [[Special Air Service]](SAS)].<ref>http://www.andrew-drummond.com/2014/05/murdered-canadian-journalist-was-spook.html Andrew Drummond, "Murdered Canadian Journalist was a Spook", ''Thailand's Alternative News Site'', May 3, 2014.</ref>
After his term of enlistment ended, Walker returned to Canada and worked as a private investigator and eventually began travelling to S.E. Asia on assignments. In the late 1980s he famously located a missing refugee girl from Cambodia whom he re-united with her refugee family in Canada.<ref>https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eowibN3NnUc CTV NEWS ''W-5'' (circa)1986</ref> While in Canada Walker worked with CSIS ([[Canadian Security Intelligence Service]]) identifying [[Khmer Rouge]] genocide perpetrators who had infiltrated into Canada among Cambodian refugees in the 1980s.<ref>Chris Doucette, "Canadian found dead in Cambodia provided help to intelligence agents, ''Toronto Sun'', May 2, 2014.</ref><ref>https://www.ctvnews.ca/world/body-of-missing-canadian-filmmaker-dave-walker-found-in-cambodia-1.1800830 CTV News Channel, "Body of missing Canadian filmmaker Dave Walker found in Cambodia, May 1, 2014</ref>
In the late 1980s and early 1990s, Walker trained [[Karen National Liberation Army]] insurgents on the Thailand-Myanmar border, where he met his wife in a remote northern Thai village. He brought her to Canada and after five years they divorced amicably. {{citation needed|date=February 2018}}
During the 1990s-2000s Walker worked as a freelance photo-journalist, screenwriter and movie production fixer on films like ''[[The Beach (film)]]'' and with ABC News' [[Diane Sawyer]] on her coverage of the Tsunami in 2004. He worked with Canadian filmmakers [[Peter Lynch (director)|Peter Lynch]] and [[Peter Vronsky]] in [[Toronto]] and [[Cambodia]].{{citation needed|date=February 2018}} In 1998, Walker published a book of love letters he co-edited from Bangkok bar girls to their foreign boyfriends, ''Hello My Big, Big Honey!''<ref>https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/2295540.Hello_My_Big_Big_Honey_</ref>{{better source|date=February 2018}}
In the early 1990s, Walker was co-producing an independent feature film he had written, ''The Man From Year Zero'' with actor [[Haing S. Ngor]] from the movie ''[[The Killing Fields (film)]]''. Walker's screenplay described how Cambodian refugees in Canada encounter a former Khmer Rouge executioner hiding among them and was going to feature Ngor in the role of the fugitive perpetrator. But after Ngor was murdered by Cambodian gang members in Los Angeles in 1996, the project collapsed.<ref>https://web.archive.org/web/20140307064225/http://www.animistfarmfilms.com:80/stories Howls From the Gang Module</ref>
In 2009, Walker earned an M.A. at York University in Toronto in the field of Augmented Reality before returning to Cambodia.<ref>http://interdis.gradstudies.yorku.ca/alumni-spotlight/ York University Graduate Program in Interdisciplinary Studies Alumni Spotlight</ref> As part of his M.A. thesis, Walker made a short film ''The Augmented Cambodian''.<ref>https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=otZfUdpL3tw "The Augmented Cambodian on YouTube.</ref>
Walker continued to explore themes in Cambodia's history and in 2012 he returned to Cambodia to begin researching a documentary ''The Poorest Man'', the story of an "[[Oskar Schindler]]"-like former Khmer Rouge village chief who risked his life to save victims in his village from the [[Pol Pot]] regime's genocidal killings. As many of the Khmer Rouge perpetrators had returned to Cambodia in the 1990s, and re-entered government service, police, military and business, and were now claiming that they "had no choice" in perpetrating their crimes under Pol Pot, Walker's proposed film about the one Khmer Rouge functionary who demonstrated they did had a choice and survived Pol Pot just the same, was met with hostility from some sectors in Cambodia.<ref>https://web.archive.org/web/20140302102400/http://www.animistfarmfilms.com:80/projects The Poorest Man</ref>
==Disappearance and death== On February 14, 2014, Walker disappeared after he left his guest house in Cambodia. Hotel staff stated room service cleaning staff went to Walker's room around 2pm and he said he would leave the room so the room could be cleaned. He left with a bottle of water in hand and never returned.<ref>http://www.ifj.org/nc/news-single-view/category/blog/article/canadian-journalist-still-missing-in-cambodia/ International Federation of Journalists "Canadian Journalist Still Missing in Cambodia" 6 Mar 2014</ref>
Cambodian Police and Canada's foreign affairs department [[Global Affairs Canada]] bungled and obstructed the investigation of Walker's mysterious disappearance,{{citation needed|date=February 2018}} while several different private investigations began to duel with each other in bitter rivalry.<ref name=globe/><ref>http://www.phnompenhpost.com/siem-reap-insider/man-about-town-28-march-2014 Peter Olszewski, "Delving into Dave Walker's Disappearance", Phnom Pehn Post, 28 March 2014</ref>
On May 1, Walker's body was found at Cambodia's [[Angkor]] Temple Complex, near the "Gates of Death" at Angkor Thom, approximately 13 kilometers from where he disappeared. Two autopsy reports, (one commissioned by Walker's family) could not determine a cause of death but indicated that Walker died many weeks before his body was discovered, probably on the day of his disappearance.{{citation needed|date=February 2018}} Walker's body was recovered by his ex-wife's family, cremated and his ashes enshrined in the northern Thai village where he had met his wife, as per his wishes.{{citation needed|date=February 2018}}
His disappearance and death remain unsolved.
