Houston, Harris County, Texas, United States | resting_place = | monuments = | residence = | nationality = | other_names = | ethnicity = | citizenship = | education = | alma_mater = | occupation = | years_active = | employer = | organization = | known_for = Unidentified victim of homicide | home_town = | salary = | net_worth = | height = Between {{height|ft=5|in=4|abbr=mos}}
and {{height|ft=5|in=8|abbr=mos}}(approximate) | weight = | religion = | denomination = | criminal_charge = | criminal_penalty = | criminal_status = | spouse = | partner = | children = | parents = | relatives = | awards = | signature = | signature_alt = | signature_size = | module = | website = | footnotes = | box_width = }} '''The Harris County Does''' consist of two currently unidentified youths discovered on January 12, 1981 in Houston, Harris County, Texas near Wallisville Road. Extensive investigation has been conducted with few leads. ==Victims== Both victims, a male and female, were found [[murder]]ed, approximately eight weeks to two months before, between November and December 1980.{{cite web|title=Jane Doe 1981|url=http://www.missingkids.org/poster/NCMU/1184342|website=missingkids.org|publisher=[[National Center for Missing and Exploited Children]]|accessdate=25 October 2014}}{{cite web|title=Harris Texas Jane Doe January 1981|url=http://www.canyouidentifyme.org/HarrisTexasJaneDoeJanuary1981|website=canyouidentifyme.org|accessdate=25 October 2014}} Although their weights were impossible to estimate and the faces were not recognizable due to decomposition, their [[fingerprint]]s, [[dentition|dental]] records and [[DNA]] were taken.{{cite web|title=NamUs UP # 701|url=https://identifyus.org/cases/701|website=identifyus.org|publisher=[[National Missing and Unidentified Persons Database]]|accessdate=25 October 2014|date=15 November 2007}} Both of their bodies were hidden on private property in the woods around 100 yards from the road and later found by a dog. They were both buried in indigent graves near to the then-unidentified [[murder of Michelle Garvey|Michelle Garvey]], who was later identified and transported to Connecticut in 2014.{{cite news|last1=Olsen|first1=Lise|title='Detective' will exhume bodies in victim identity hunt|url=http://www.chron.com/news/houston-texas/article/Detective-will-exhume-bodies-in-victim-identity-1691577.php#ixzz1Nx3nb9AT|accessdate=8 December 2014|work=Houston Chronicle|date=30 May 2011}} ===Female victim=== The female, who was [[White Americans|white]] with a possible [[Native Americans in the United States|Native American]]-[[Miscegenation|admixture]], was between the ages of eighteen and twenty five, although she may have been as young as fifteen. The cause of her death was ruled to be strangulation.{{cite news|last1=Betz|first1=Dean|title=Cold cases: Details on 28 cold murder cases from 1952 to 1999|url=http://blog.chron.com/newswatch/2011/05/cold-cases-database/?appSession=65520750810396085794059232210142370687217307775633549589536034475383023035791506505497665530170006310369580557793064061265385052&RecordID=6&PageID=8&PrevPageID=2&cpipage=1&CPIsortType=&CPIorderBy=&cbCurrentRecordPosition=6&Mod0LinkToDetails=True|accessdate=23 December 2015|work=Houston Chronicle|publisher=[[Hearst Newspapers, LLC]]|date=30 May 2011}} She was estimated to have been around five feet four inches to five feet nine inches tall. Her hair was eighteen inches long and reddish-brown, styled in a [[ponytail]]. Her eyes were believed to have been brown and both of her ears were likely pierced, although only one earring was found in her right ear. She had excellent dental hygiene, as did her companion.{{cite news|last1=Olsen|first1=Lise|title=Investigators hope DNA provides answers in 30-year-old murder|url=http://www.chron.com/news/houston-texas/article/Investigators-hope-DNA-provides-answers-in-2296253.php|accessdate=23 January 2018|work=Houston Chronicle|date=27 November 2011}} The victim was found near a pair of green jogging shorts and a "bloody towel" and no clothing was found on her body. What are considered to be identifying factors for the girl is that she likely had an abnormal amount of hair on her face and she had a gap between her two front teeth. The victim was presumably a [[nail biting|nail biter]], as her [[fingernail]]s were noticeably short.{{cite web|title=Case File 476UFTX|url=http://www.doenetwork.org/cases/476uftx.html|website=doenetwork.org|publisher=[[The Doe Network]]|accessdate=25 October 2014}} Her wisdom teeth were emerging at the time of death. Nine missing people from Texas and one from Pennsylvania have been ruled out as possible identities of the female. ===Male victim=== The male was somewhat older, estimated to be twenty to thirty years old, although he could have been as young as fifteen. Like the female, he was also white, had brown eyes and brown hair, although it was wavy and six inches long. The male was around five feet four to five feet eight inches tall at the time of his murder, which had been committed through beating. Unlike the female, he was bound and gagged. He had prominent [[eyebrow]]s and some deterioration of some of his upper [[vertebrae]] in the neck region, possibly the result of an injury in the past or the presence of an abnormal joint.{{cite web|title=Harris Texas John Doe January 1981|url=http://canyouidentifyme.org/HarrisTexasJohnDoeJanuary1981|website=canyouidentifyme.org|accessdate=25 October 2014}} As for dentals, one [[dental filling|filling]] was found in one of the [[molars]]; he also had restorations and his upper [[wisdom teeth]] were not found, as they may have been [[root canal|removed]] or they may not have developed.{{cite web|title=Case File 753UMTX|url=http://www.doenetwork.org/cases/753umtx.html|website=doenetwork.org|publisher=[[The Doe Network]]|accessdate=25 October 2014}} Six missing men were ruled out as possible identities for the male victim.{{cite web|title=NamUs UP # 703|url=https://www.identifyus.org/en/cases/703|website=identifyus.org|publisher=[[National Missing and Unidentified Persons System]]|accessdate=25 October 2014|date=15 November 2007}} ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== {{commons category|Unidentified murder victims}} *{{NCMEC UID|1184342|Female victim}} *{{Doe Network|476uftx.html|Female victim}} *{{NamUs|701|Female victim}} *{{Doe Network|753umtx.html|Male victim}} *{{NamUs|703|Male victim}} {{Unidentified decedent}} [[Category:Unidentified murder victims in Texas]] [[Category:People murdered in Texas]] [[Category:Unsolved murders in the United States]] [[Category:1980 deaths]] [[Category:Murdered American children]] [[Category:Deaths by person in the United States]] [[Category:People who were forensically reconstructed]] [[Category:1980 in Texas]] [[Category:People from Houston]] [[Category:20th-century births]] [[Category:1980 murders in the United States]] [[Category:1981 deaths]] [[Category:1981 in Texas]] [[Category:Deaths by strangulation in the United States]] [[Category:Deaths by beating in the United States]]

{{EngvarB|date=September 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2014}} '''Sir Jerome Alexander''' (c.1585–1670) was an English-born [[barrister]], judge and politician who spent much of his career in [[Ireland]] (after he had been professionally ruined in England) and became a substantial Irish landowner. He was a noted benefactor of [[Trinity College Dublin]]. As a judge he was so ruthless in securing guilty verdicts, and in imposing the [[death penalty]], that for many years after his death the saying "to be Alexandered" was an Irish [[synonym]] for being hanged.<ref>Ball, F. Elrington ''The Judges in Ireland 1221–1921'' John Murray London 1926 Vol.1 p.282</ref>
==Early career==
His precise date of birth is uncertain, but he was stated in 1637 to be several years older than Sir Maurice Eustace, who was born about 1590. He was born at [[Gressenhall]], [[Norfolk]], the eldest son of Jerome Alexander senior of Thorpland, an employee of [[Thomas Howard, 21st Earl of Arundel]]; the younger Jerome was also employed for a time as steward and [[bailiff]] to the Earl, and remained on friendly terms with him in later life. Elrington Ball states that the Alexander family were of [[Jewish]] origin.<ref>Ball p.348</ref> He was educated at [[Aylsham]] school, and then at [[Gonville and Caius College, Cambridge]], where he matriculated in 1609.<ref>''Biographical Dictionary of Gonville and Caius College 1349–1895'' (1897) Vol.1 p.203 </ref> He entered [[Furnivall's Inn]] and then proceeded to [[Lincoln's Inn]] in 1617, and was [[called to the bar]] in 1623.<ref>Ball p.348</ref>
===Disgrace===
His legal career was destroyed by a finding of [[professional misconduct]] against him: unusually, this did not arise from his services to a client. He was, unlike most barristers, very litigious on his own behalf, and in 1626 the [[Star Chamber]] found him guilty of [[tampering with evidence]] in one of his own lawsuits; he was [[disbarred]], fined and given a prison sentence. He moved to Ireland, where he entered the [[King's Inn]] and began to practice at the [[Irish Bar]]. It is unclear if the Benchers of the King's Inn were then aware of his criminal record; if not, they certainly learned of it within the next few years. In 1633 he received a [[Royal pardon]], on condition that he did not return to legal practice in England. In 1644 he published his ''Breviate'', a 100-page [[pamphlet]] in defence of his actions.<ref>Ball p.348</ref> It gives a valuable, if inevitably slanted picture of his early life, and describes all his misfortunes as being due to the machinations of his enemies (this was to be a constant theme of Alexander's throughout his life).<ref>Ball p.266</ref>
==Politics==
He entered politics, and sat in the [[Irish House of Commons]] as MP for [[Lifford (Parliament of Ireland constituency)|Lifford]] in the [[Parliament of Ireland|Parliament]] of 1634–5 and that of 1639–49. He was a friend and client of the wealthy and influential young nobleman [[James Butler, 1st Duke of Ormonde]], who granted him the impressive dwelling [[Kilcooly Abbey]] in [[County Tipperary]]; he was also granted lands near [[Kells, County Meath]].<ref>Ball p.348</ref>
He was also befriended by other influential figures in Ireland, including [[James Ussher]], [[Archbishop of Armagh]]: but his hope of further career advancement was destroyed by the arrival in Ireland of the new [[Lord Lieutenant of Ireland|Lord Lieutenant]], [[Thomas Wentworth, 1st Earl of Strafford]], who despised Alexander and described him with contempt as "a scurvy [[puritan]]". Strafford, who became almost all-powerful in Ireland, and who was well aware that Alexander had been professionally disgraced in England, vetoed his appointment as an extra judge of [[assize]] in 1637: <ref>Hart, A. R. ''History of the King's Serjeants-at-law in Ireland'' Dublin Four Courts Press 2000 pp.50-51 </ref>the ostensible reason was that only Sir [[Maurice Eustace (Lord Chancellor)|Maurice Eustace]], the [[Serjeant-at-law (Ireland)|King's Serjeant]] was qualified to act as an extra judge, but Strafford's references to Eustace as a "man of integrity" can also be read as an attack on Alexander's character.<ref>Hart pp.50-51</ref> He refused him leave to go to England, and when Alexander went to England anyway he was imprisoned in the [[Fleet Prison]], nor following his release was he able to return to Ireland until after Strafford's downfall. Given the enmity between the two men, it is not surprising that Alexander was active in the [[impeachment]] of Strafford in 1641.<ref>Ball p.348</ref>
[[File:KilcooleyTower2.jpg|thumb|right|150px|[[Kilcooley Abbey]], which was granted to Alexander.]]
==Civil War==
He returned briefly to Ireland after Strafford's death, but on the outbreak of the [[Irish Rebellion of 1641]] went back to England. He was an active [[Royalist]], and attempted to raise troops to subdue Ireland; at the same time he was among those who urged [[Charles I of England|the King]], if necessary, to make an alliance with [[Confederate Ireland|the Irish Confederacy]]. For attempting to arrange such an alliance he was briefly imprisoned by Parliament in 1643, and on his release he went abroad. He was in the service of [[Charles II of England|Charles II]] at the [[Hague]] in 1650, and was active in raising money for his cause, but he returned to Ireland in 1655.<ref>Ball p.348</ref> He made his peace with the new regime, and acquired an estate in [[County Westmeath]]; but in view of the rewards he received in 1660, (even if they were not overly generous), there is no reason to doubt that he remained a Royalist at heart.<ref>Ball p.279</ref>
==Restoration==
At the [[Restoration of Charles II]], Alexander claimed to have played a major part in securing the support of the Irish Government for the new regime (in fact there was virtually no opposition in Ireland to the Restoration), and he complained at length about the great losses he had suffered during the [[Interregnum (1649-1660)|Interregnum]]. He was rewarded with a [[knighthood]] and a place on the [[Court of Common Pleas (Ireland)]], no doubt largely though the influence of the Duke of Ormonde, who had the last word on appointments to the Irish Bench at the Restoration, and was always loyal (some thought overly so) to old friends like Alexander. Nonetheless Alexander was plainly dissatisfied at ranking only as second justice of the Court: he claimed that he should have been given the office of [[Chief Justice of the Irish Common Pleas]], and quarreled with Sir [[William Aston (Irish judge)|William Aston]], justice of the [[Court of King's Bench (Ireland)]] over which of them had precedence. Rumour had it that he challenged Aston to a [[duel]] on the issue, but to Alexander's disgust Aston refused the challenge.<ref>Ball p.279</ref> He also acted as legal adviser to the future King [[James II]] on his Irish affairs.<ref>Ball p.349</ref>
==Judge==
He was a stern enforcer of religious conformity: in his [[will (law)|will]] he refers to the [[Church of England]] as "the best form of Government in all this world". On the [[Ulster]] circuit, to which he was regularly assigned, he became noted for severity against non-conforming Protestants: his ally [[John Bramhall]], [[Bishop of Derry]] wrote that if the non-conformists "could not love him, they began to fear him".<ref>Ball pp.282–3</ref>
===Religious beliefs and attitudes===
It has been suggested that he had an equally harsh attitude towards [[Roman Catholics]], but that he was unable to show similar severity towards them, due to the relaxed attitude of the Duke of Ormonde, now Lord Lieutenant of Ireland. Ormonde recognised that since Catholics were a large majority of the Irish population, a generous if unofficial measure of toleration of that faith was inevitable.<ref>Kenyon, J.P. ''The Popish Plot'' Phoenix Press reissue 2000 p.224</ref> However Alexander's attitude to Roman Catholics was perhaps more complex than this: he was, for example, on friendly terms with the well-known Catholic barrister [[Patrick D'Arcy]], who offered to act as his second in the abortive duel with Sir William Aston.<ref>Burke, Oliver ''Anecdotes of the Connaught Circuit'' Hodges Figgis Dublin 1885 p.64</ref> Through marriage Alexander himself had Catholic connections: his wife Elizabeth Havers belonged to a staunchly Roman Catholic family [http://www.catholic-history.org.uk/cfhs/catholic_ancestor_20130203.htm#V7]. Her ancestor Mr Havers of Thelton Hall built a chapel on the grounds of Thelton Hall which became the hub of the Catholic community in and around Diss, Norfolk, before during and after the oppression. Elizabeth's elder brother William Havers, who inherited Thelton in 1651, and who died in 1670, was a known [[Recusancy|recusant]]. This suggests that Alexander, like many Protestants of his time, was prepared to turn a blind eye to recusancy when it was practiced by his own friends or relatives, and even to marry into an openly Catholic family himself.<ref>cf. Kenyon ''Popish Plot'' p.7</ref>
=="Alexandered"== The Duke of Ormonde, who was a merciful man by the standards of the time, is known to have disapproved of Alexander's notorious severity in criminal trials. This attitude was in notable contrast to the conduct of most other Irish judges of the time who were, like Ormonde, inclined to clemency. Where Ormonde would always reprieve a man where he could, Alexander, it was said, would hang as many men as ''he'' could : on one occasion he sentenced fourteen men to death at a single assize. His reputation for severity became such that for many years after his death "to be '''Alexandered"''' was widely used in Ireland as a synonym for "to be hanged".<ref>Ball p.282</ref>
==Death and will==
He died in the summer of 1670, and was buried in [[St Patrick's Cathedral, Dublin]]. Much of his property, including Kilcooley Abbey, passed to his daughter Elizabeth, on condition that she did not marry an Irishman (she did not); he also left £100 to each of the three children of his eldest surviving daughter Jeromina Langham. His law books and other texts he left to Trinity College Dublin, with enough money to pay for a librarian,<ref>Kenny, Colum ''King's Inns and the Kingdom of Ireland'' Irish Academic Press Dublin 1992 p.193</ref> (the King's Inns, of which he was a senior member, had no facilities for storing books at the time, and had to wait till 1788 for the foundation of its own library).<ref>Kenny p.193</ref> His friend Sir [[Edward Massey]] received many of his personal valuables and curiosities, such as "my cane with the silver head of a [[rhinoceros]]".<ref>Ball pp.284–5</ref> As he had already done in his ''Breviate'', he dwelt in his will on the machinations of his enemies, and rejoiced that God's grace had enabled him to triumph over them. More humanely, he noted that God in return required him to help the poor and needy.<ref>Ball p.284</ref>
Ball suggests that he would have been most unhappy had he known that his place on the Bench would be taken by [[Oliver Jones (judge)|Oliver Jones]], who was noted for his impartiality towards Roman Catholics, and was widely suspected of being a secret Catholic himself. However it seems that Alexander, whose wife was a member of a notable Roman Catholic family, may have been more tolerant of the Catholic faith in private than his severe public stance suggested .<ref>Ball p.286</ref>
==Family==
Alexander married Elizabeth Havers,<ref>The Will, dated 1651, of John Havers of Shelfanger, names his daughter Elizabeth Alexander and his son in Law, Jerome Alexander</ref> a daughter of John Havers of Shelfhanger, a noted recusant, who like Alexander's father was an employee of the Earl of Arundel, and his wife Elizabeth Tindal of Banham; she died in 1667.<ref>Cokayne ''The Complete Baronetage'' Reprinted Gloucester 1983 Vol. IV p.74</ref> They had sixteen children, many of whom died young; but at least three of his daughters survived their father:
*Jeromina, who married Humphrey Langham, and had at least five children; *Rose, who married firstly Roger Mallock of Cockington, [[Devon]], and secondly [[Thomas Gorges (Maine)|Thomas Gorges]], Deputy Governor of [[Maine]], and died in 1671, leaving a son and a daughter; *Elizabeth, who heeded her father's warning that he would disinherit her if she married an Irishman, and instead married an Englishman, Sir William Barker, first of the [[Barker baronets]] of Bocking Hall, [[Essex]]. She died in 1702, leaving issue, including Sir William Barker, 2nd Baronet.<ref>Cokayne p.74</ref>
==Personality==
Elrington Ball describes Alexander as a "strongly complex character".<ref>Ball p.284</ref> He was a bitter enemy but a good friend; he was merciless towards criminals, but charitable towards the poor. Throughout his life he was inclined to blame his misfortunes on the machinations of his enemies, even those disasters which to any detached observer would seem to be entirely his own fault. As a young [[barrister]] he was found guilty of misconduct, but as a judge prided himself on not taking bribes.<ref>Ball p.283</ref> He publicly called for the persecution of Roman Catholics, but married into an openly Catholic family. Burke called him a man of strong passions, but also a man of great integrity and public spirit.<ref>Burke ''Anecdotes'' p.64</ref>
==Published works== *''A Breviate of a sentence given against Jerome Alexander, utter-barrister of Lincoln's Inn, in the Court of Star Chamber... with exceptions taken to the said sentence to unfold the iniquity thereof." Published in [[London]] in 1644.<ref>Ball p.266</ref>
==References== {{reflist|2}}
{{authority control}}

{{About|the Ole Miss Rebels offensive lineman born in 1887|the Notre Dame Fighting Irish offensive lineman born in 1921|John Adams (offensive lineman)}} {{Infobox college football player |name=John C. Adams |image=redadams.png |image_size=150px |school=Ole Miss Rebels |birth_date={{birth date|1887|3|2}} |birth_place=[[Kosciusko, Mississippi]] |pastschools=[[Ole Miss Rebels football|Ole Miss]] (1909–1912) |class=Graduate |major=Medicine |currentposition=[[Center (American football)|Center]] |weight_lb=180 |height_ft=6 |height_in=1 |highlights= *[[College Football All-Southern Team|All-Southern]] ([[1912 College Football All-Southern Team|1912]]) }} '''John Charles "Red" Adams''' (March 2, 1887 – ?) was a [[college football]] player.
==University of Mississippi== He was a prominent [[Center (American football)|center]] for the [[Ole Miss Rebels football]] team of the [[University of Mississippi]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mocavo.com/Ole-Miss-University-of-Mississippi-1911/349335/157|title=Foot Ball Team and Statistics}}</ref> Adams was nominated though not selected for an ''Associated Press'' All-Time Southeast 1869-1919 era team.<ref name="allt">{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1242&dat=19690731&id=TkdTAAAAIBAJ&sjid=YoYDAAAAIBAJ&pg=2604,3160960|newspaper=Kingsport Post|title=U-T Greats On All-Time Southeast Team|date=July 31, 1969}}</ref> ===1912=== Adams was [[Captain (sports)|captain]] of the [[1912 Ole Miss Rebels football team|1912 team]]. He was selected [[College Football All-Southern Team|All-Southern]] by [[Nathan Stauffer]] of ''[[Collier's Weekly]]''.<ref name="1913sp">{{cite book|url=https://archive.org/stream/officialnational08nati#page/64/mode/2up/search/%22all+southern%22|title=Spalding's Football Guide|date=1913|via=[[archive.org]]|accessdate=March 5, 2015|pages=25, 65}}{{Open access}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hXcjAQAAMAAJ&pg=RA12-PA13#v=onepage&q&f=false|journal=Collier's Weekly|volume=50|page=13|title=Collier's All-Southern Football Team|author=Nathan P. Stauffer|via=[[Google books]]|accessdate=March 5, 2015}} {{Open access}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Adams, John C.}} {{Collegefootball-player-stub}}

{{Infobox officeholder | name = Joe Barker | office = 17th [[List of mayors of Pittsburgh|Mayor of Pittsburgh]] | image = File:Mayor Joe Barker Daguerreotype.jpg | caption = Mayor Joseph Barker
{{circa}} 1850 | predecessor = [[John Herron (Pittsburgh)|John Herron]] | successor = [[John B. Guthrie]] | footnotes = | party =Write-In | birth_date = ca. 1806 | birth_place = [[Pennsylvania]] | death_date = August 2, 1862 (age 55/56) | death_place = [[Manchester (Pittsburgh)|Manchester]], Pennsylvania | death_cause = Decapitation | resting_place = [[Allegheny Cemetery]] | spouse =Jane Holmes | relations = | residence = | alma_mater = | occupation = | religion = | website = | term_start = January 8, 1850 | term_end = January, 1851 }} '''Joseph "Joe" Barker''' (ca. 1806– August 2, 1862) {{Cite web|url = http://freepages.genealogy.rootsweb.ancestry.com/~njm1/10-ALLEGHENY%20BUTLER%20ST.-SEC.%2029,%20LOT%20196-BARKER,%20JOSEPH%20AND%20JANE.JPG|title = Epitaph|date = August 2, 1862|accessdate = January 10, 2016|website = |publisher = |last = |first = }} was an American public and political figure of the 1800s remembered to this day for his rash, uncompromising temper, and violent tirades against corruption, often drawing large crowds, landing him in prison, and paving way for his term in office as the 17th mayor of [[Pittsburgh]]. ==Early years== The origins of Joe Barker are shrouded in mystery: nothing is known of his early years, background, or even his date of birth, as evident by its absence on his [[epitaph]]. [[File:Portrait_of_Mayor_Joseph_Barker.jpg]] == Appearance == Barker's appearance, in contrast to what was common of the era, was described as always cleanly shaven and well-dressed in nearly all black attire. It was said of him never to be seen without a neckcloth, black stovepipe hat, and long black cape. == 1850 Census == Important, although sparse, details are provided in the information collected by the [[United States Census, 1850|Census of 1850]]. Barker is listed therein as 44 years old and living in Pittsburgh's Fifth [[Wards of the United States|Ward]] with his Irish-born wife Jane Holmes and three children, Charles Augustus, Eliza, and David. His birthplace is described as being in "Pennsylvania", and his occupation is given as "Mayor". Contrary to propaganda spread by his enemies, and even incorrectly referenced in articles to this day, Barker was far from illiterate, as clearly indicated on the 1850 census; he was instead described as having a silver tongue.{{Cite web|url=http://digital.library.pitt.edu/cgi-bin/census/census_driver.pl?searchtype=full_record&key=25658&database=Pittsburgh_1850|title=Historic Pittsburgh - Census 1850|website=digital.library.pitt.edu|access-date=2016-04-05}} As a perhaps sardonic nod to his opposition, Barker chose to leave the "sane" category on the census unchecked.{{Cite web|url=http://digital.library.pitt.edu/cgi-bin/census/census_driver.pl?searchtype=full_record&key=25658&database=Pittsburgh_1850|title=Historic Pittsburgh - Census 1850|website=digital.library.pitt.edu|access-date=2016-04-05}} == Arrest, Imprisonment, and Election == Joe Barker gained vast public attention and notoriety as a [[street preacher]] of the violent class, vehemently attacking political corruption. In November 1849, a riot broke out following one of Barker's more extreme tirades in [[Market Square (Pittsburgh)|Market Square]], Mayor [[John Herron (Pittsburgh)|John Herron]] had him arrested on three counts: * Inciting a riot * Obstructing traffic * Using lewd and indecent language in the delivery of incendiary threats{{Cite news|url=|title="The Commonwealth v Barker et al."|last=|first=|date=20 November 1849|work=Pittsburgh Daily Post|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|publication-place=Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania|page=1}} On November 19 the charges resulted in a fine and 12-month jail sentence, but Barker did not exactly display remorse, stating, "''Judge Patton made a threat two weeks ago of what he would do if I was thrown into his power. Now let him touch me if he dares. I'll hang him to a lamppost if he lays a finger on me''." The next mayoral election was fast approaching, and Barker's nativist supporters circulated a [[write-in candidate|write-in petition]] during his imprisonment which resulted in his election as mayor to succeed Herron. Accounts of Barker's one-year 1850–51 term describe it as a period of religious and nativist strife. == Death == Barker lived for eleven years after leaving the mayoralty and despite a number of additional attempts, never again held public office. He was in his mid-fifties at the time of his decapitation in a train accident in the neighboring town of [[Manchester (Pittsburgh)|Manchester]] (a part of Pittsburgh since 1908). Interment was in [[Allegheny Cemetery]]. == References == {{Portal|Pittsburgh|Biography|Politics}} ==External links== {{s-start}} {{succession box | before=[[John Herron (Pittsburgh)|John Herron]] | title=[[Mayor of Pittsburgh]] | years=1850–1851 | after=[[John B. Guthrie]]}} {{s-end}} {{Mayors of Pittsburgh}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Barker, Joseph}} [[Category:Mayors of Pittsburgh]] [[Category:Anti-Catholicism in the United States]] [[Category:Railway accident deaths in the United States]] [[Category:Accidental deaths in Pennsylvania]] [[Category:1806 births]] [[Category:1862 deaths]] [[Category:Place of birth unknown]] [[Category:Date of birth unknown]] [[Category:Burials at Allegheny Cemetery]] [[Category:19th-century American politicians]]

revision.comment: Corrected Infobox reference to 'Second' degree murder, so that it refers to Mr. Tate's actual charge of 'First' degree murder.
revision.text:
{{Infobox criminal | name = Lionel Tate | image_name = Lionel Tate Mugshot.jpg | image_size = 200px | image_caption = Photo of Tate | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1987|1|30}} | birth_place = [[Broward County, Florida]], United States | alias = | conviction = First-degree [[murder]], [[probation violation]] and armed [[robbery]] | conviction_penalty = Life in prison without parole [[state prison]] | conviction_status = [[Incarceration|Incarcerated]] at the Appalachian Correctional Institution in Sneads, Florida | occupation = | spouse = | parents = | children = }} '''Lionel Alexander Tate''' (born January 30, 1987)<ref>[http://www.dc.state.fl.us/ActiveInmates/inmateaction.asp?DataAction=GetInmate&DCNumber=L24475 Inmate Population Information Detail<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> is the youngest American citizen ever sentenced to [[life imprisonment]] without possibility of [[parole]].<ref>https://www.cbsnews.com/news/lionel-tate-gets-30-years-in-jail/</ref> In January 2001, when Tate was 13, he was convicted of first-degree [[murder]] for the 1999 battering death of 6-year-old Tiffany Eunick in [[Broward County, Florida]].<ref>https://www.nytimes.com/2001/03/10/us/sentence-of-life-without-parole-for-boy-14-in-murder-of-girl-6.html</ref>
==Murder== On July 28, 1999 Tate was left alone with Eunick, who was being babysat by Tate's mother, Kathleen Grossett-Tate. While the children were downstairs playing, Tate's mother called to them to be quiet. Tate came up 45 minutes later to say that Eunick was not breathing. He stated that they were wrestling, he had her in a head lock and the child's head hit a table.
===Conviction=== Tate was convicted of killing Eunick by stomping on her so forcefully that her liver was lacerated.<ref name="LiverLacerated">Abby Goodnough, "Youngster Given Life Term For Killing Gets New Trial," The New York Times, December 11, 2003</ref> Her other injuries included a fractured skull, fractured rib and swollen brain. These injuries were characterized by the prosecution as "similar to those she would have sustained by falling from a three-story building."<ref name="ThreeStoryFall">Dana Canedy, "Boy Convicted of Murder in Wrestling Death," The New York Times, January 5, 2001</ref> In sentencing Tate to life imprisonment, Judge [[Joel T. Lazarus]] of Broward County Circuit Court said that "The acts of Lionel Tate were not the playful acts of a child [...] The acts of Lionel Tate were cold, callous and indescribably cruel."<ref name="NatureOfAttacks">Dana Canedy, " Sentence of Life Without Parole For Boy, 13, in Murder of Girl, 6 ," The New York Times, March 10, 2001</ref>
====Felony murder rule ==== Florida Statutes required the jury to convict Tate of first-degree murder even if the jury did not believe that he intended to kill or injure anyone—all that was required was that Tate knowingly abused another child who died as a result (wherein any intentional act that could reasonably be expected to result in physical injury to a child is ''child abuse'' per Florida statutes).<ref>[http://www.leg.state.fl.us/Statutes/index.cfm?App_mode=Display_Statute&Search_String=&URL=0700-0799/0782/Sections/0782.04.html Statutes & Constitution :View Statutes : Online Sunshine<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref>[http://www.leg.state.fl.us/Statutes/index.cfm?App_mode=Display_Statute&Search_String=&URL=0800-0899/0827/Sections/0827.03.html Statutes & Constitution :View Statutes : Online Sunshine<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref>[http://www.leg.state.fl.us/Statutes/index.cfm?App_mode=Display_Statute&Search_String=&URL=0700-0799/0784/Sections/0784.045.html Statutes & Constitution :View Statutes : Online Sunshine<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
The rule for such convictions is known as the [[Felony murder rule (Florida)|felony murder rule]]. The sufficient conditions of the felony murder rule were listed by the judge [[Joel T. Lazarus]] during sentencing.<ref>[http://transcripts.cnn.com/TRANSCRIPTS/0103/09/se.04.html Wrestling Death: Judge Sentences Lionel Tate, 14, to Life in Prison]</ref>
Thus Tate was sentenced to life in prison without the prosecution having to prove that he intended to kill or injure, or realized that his acts are likely to kill or injure, or even that a typical child of his age would or should realize this.
Critics, such as the various groups listed in the Amicus Brief attached to Tate's appeal, assert that convicting preteen children of 1st-degree murder without having to prove these children intended any harm, not to mention serious injury or death, is unacceptable.<ref>[http://www.law.ufl.edu/centers/childlaw/pdf/tate.pdf STATE OF FLORIDA IN THE FOURTH DISTRICT COURT OF APPEAL Case No. 4D01-1306] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100702183114/http://www.law.ufl.edu/centers/childlaw/pdf/tate.pdf |date=July 2, 2010 }}</ref><ref>[http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/2001-05-14/news/0105130340_1_felony-murder-rule-felony-murder-rule-prosecutors Rule Should Not Apply To Children]</ref>
===Sentence=== The sentence was controversial because Tate was 12 years old at the time of the death, and his victim was 6. He was the youngest person in modern US history to be sentenced to life imprisonment,<ref>https://www.cbsnews.com/news/lionel-tate-gets-30-years-in-jail/</ref> bringing broad criticism on the treatment of [[Juvenile delinquency|juvenile offender]]s in the justice system of the [[U.S. state|state]] of [[Florida]].
===Original sentence overturned=== After the conviction, the prosecution openly joined Tate's plea for leniency in sentencing, and even offered to help in his appeal. The trial judge criticized the prosecution for compromising the integrity of the [[adversarial system]], and said that if the prosecution felt that life imprisonment was not warranted, they should not have charged him with murder in the first place.
In January 2004, a state appeals court overturned his conviction on the basis that his mental [[Competency evaluation (law)|competency had not been evaluated]] before trial. This opened the way for Tate to accept the same plea deal he originally turned down, and he was released on one year's [[house arrest]] and 10 years' [[probation]].
==Probation violation== On September 3, 2004, Tate was detained and held in prison for violating the terms of his house arrest when he was found out of his house and carrying an eight-inch knife.<ref>[http://www.miaminewtimes.com/news/free-lionel-tate-6377917 Free Lionel Tate | Miami New Times<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
==Armed robbery arrest and subsequent plea bargain== On May 23, 2005, Tate was charged with armed burglary with battery, armed robbery and [[Probation violation|violation of probation]], the [[Broward County Sheriff's Office]] said.
Tate threatened [[Domino's Pizza]] deliveryman Walter Ernest Gallardo with a handgun outside a friend's apartment after phoning in an order. Gallardo dropped the four [[pizza]]s and fled the scene. Tate then re-entered the apartment, assaulting the occupant who did not want Tate inside.
Gallardo called [[9-1-1]] upon reaching the Domino's store and returned to identify Tate, the sheriff's office said in a statement. No gun was recovered.
On March 1, 2006, Tate accepted a plea bargain and was to be sentenced to 30 years' imprisonment in a sentencing hearing in April 2006. Tate admitted that he had violated probation by possessing a gun during the May 23 robbery that netted four pizzas worth $33.60, but he has refused to answer questions about where he got it and later disposed of the gun. He was allowed to withdraw his guilty plea for robbery, but was finally sentenced to 30 years in prison on May 18, 2006 for violating probation. On October 24, 2007, Florida's 4th District Court of Appeal upheld that sentence.<ref>[http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/nationworld/2003975547_ndig26.html Court upholds sentence for Tate] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090418132033/http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/nationworld/2003975547_ndig26.html |date=2009-04-18 }}</ref>
On February 19, 2008, Tate pleaded [[Nolo contendere|no contest]] to the pizza robbery and was sentenced to 10 years in state prison. The sentence will run concurrently with his 30-year sentence for violating his probation.<ref>[http://www.miamiherald.com/top_stories/story/425954.html]{{dead link|date=August 2015}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.tgorski.com/news_analysis/lionel_tate_sentencing.htm Article on Tate's original sentencing] * [http://www.miaminewtimes.com/2007-08-02/news/free-lionel-tate/ Free Lionel Tate]
{{Authority control}}

page.title: List of Presidents of the United States who died in office

revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=May 2012}} [[File:Assassination of President Lincoln.jpg|thumb|right|280px|alt=A drawing of five people, two women and three men, the rightmost of which is shooting a gun at the man sitting next to him|An 1865 [[Currier and Ives]] colored lithograph that inaccurately depicts the [[assassination of Abraham Lincoln]]]] During the history of the United States, eight presidents have died in office.<ref name="Info Please">{{cite web |url=http://www.infoplease.com/spot/prestrivia1.html |title=Presidential Trivia |accessdate=December 21, 2008 |last=Brunner |first=Borgna |work=Info Please}}</ref> Of those eight, four were [[Assassination|assassinated]] and four died of natural causes.<ref name="IPL">{{cite web |url=http://www.ipl.org/div/farq/POTUSFARQ.html#question4 |title=Presidential and Vice Presidential Succession: Overview and Current Legislation |accessdate=December 22, 2008 |last= |first= |work=Internet Public Library |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130817215451/http://ipl.org/div/farq/POTUSFARQ.html#question4#question4 |archive-date=August 17, 2013 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref> In all eight cases, the Vice President of the United States took over the office of presidency as part of the [[United States presidential line of succession]].<ref name="FAS">{{cite web |url=https://fas.org/sgp/crs/misc/RL31761.pdf |title=Presidential and Vice Presidential Succession: Overview and Current Legislation |accessdate=December 15, 2008 |last=Neale |first=Thomas H. |date=September 27, 2004 |work=Federation of American Scientists|format=PDF}}</ref>
[[William Henry Harrison]] holds the record for shortest term served, holding the office of presidency for 31 days before his death. Harrison was the first president to die in office when he caught [[pneumonia]] and died on April 4, 1841.<ref name="Harrison">{{cite web |url=https://www.loc.gov/exhibits/treasures/trr072.html |title=Harrison's Inauguration |accessdate=December 15, 2008 |work=[[Library of Congress]]}}</ref> On July 9, 1850, [[Zachary Taylor]] died from acute [[gastroenteritis]].<ref name="Taylor">{{cite web|url=http://www.whitehouse.gov/history/presidents/zt12.html |title=Zachary Taylor |accessdate=December 15, 2008 |work=[[White House]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081214021318/http://www.whitehouse.gov/history/presidents/zt12.html |archivedate=December 14, 2008 |df= }}</ref> [[Abraham Lincoln]] was the first [[List of United States presidential assassination attempts and plots|president to be assassinated]]. He was shot by [[John Wilkes Booth]] on the night of April 14, 1865 and died the following morning.<ref name="Lincoln">{{cite web |url=http://memory.loc.gov/ammem/alhtml/alrintr.html |title=Assassination of President Abraham Lincoln |accessdate=December 15, 2008 |work=[[Library of Congress]]}}</ref> Sixteen years later, on July 2, 1881, President [[James A. Garfield]] [[Assassination of James A. Garfield|was shot]] by [[Charles J. Guiteau]], surviving for over two months before dying on September 19, 1881.<ref name="Garfield">{{cite web |url=http://www.trutv.com/library/crime/terrorists_spies/assassins/charles_guiteau/index.html |title=Charles J. Guiteau |accessdate=December 15, 2008 |last=MacGowen |first=Douglas |work=Crime Library |publisher=Turner Broadcasting System, Inc |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130927195706/http://www.trutv.com/library/crime/terrorists_spies/assassins/charles_guiteau/index.html |archivedate=September 27, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> Nearly twenty years later, President [[William McKinley]] died eight days after [[Assassination of William McKinley|being shot twice]] by [[Leon Czolgosz]] on September 6, 1901.<ref name="McKinley"/> President [[Warren G. Harding]] suffered a heart attack, and died on August 2, 1923.<ref name="Harding">{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/learning/general/onthisday/bday/1102.html |title=Harding a Farm Boy Who Rose by Work |accessdate=December 15, 2008 |date=August 3, 1923 |work=[[New York Times]]}}</ref> On April 12, 1945, [[Franklin D. Roosevelt]] collapsed and died as a result of a [[cerebral hemorrhage]].<ref name="Roosevelt">{{cite web |url=http://www.whitehouse.gov/history/presidents/fr32.html |title=Franklin D. Roosevelt |accessdate=December 15, 2008 |work=[[White House]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081216123451/https://www.whitehouse.gov/history/presidents/fr32.html |archivedate=December 16, 2008 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> The most recent president to die in office was [[John F. Kennedy]], who [[Assassination of John F. Kennedy|was assassinated]] by [[Lee Harvey Oswald]] with two rifle shots on November 22, 1963, in [[Dallas]], Texas.<ref name="Kennedy">{{cite web |url=https://www.archives.gov/research/jfk/ |title=The President John F. Kennedy Assassination Records Collection |accessdate=December 15, 2008 |last= |first= |work=[[National Archives and Records Administration|National Archives]]}}</ref>
==1841: William Henry Harrison== [[File:Harrison tomb.jpg|thumb|upright|alt=A photograph of a grey-bricked structure with green trees in the background and foliage in the foreground all under a clear, blue sky|[[William Henry Harrison Tomb State Memorial|Harrison's tomb]] and memorial in [[North Bend, Ohio]]]] On March 26, 1841, [[William Henry Harrison]] became ill with a cold. According to the prevailing medical misconception of that time, it was believed that his illness was directly caused by the bad weather at his inauguration; however, Harrison's illness did not arise until more than three weeks after the event. The cold worsened, rapidly turning to [[pneumonia]] and [[pleurisy]].<ref>Cleaves 152</ref> He sought to rest in the White House, but could not find a quiet room because of the steady crowd of office seekers. His extremely busy social schedule made any rest time scarce.<ref name="loc">{{cite web | title = Harrison's Inauguration (Reason): American Treasures of the Library of Congress | publisher = [[Library of Congress]] | url = https://www.loc.gov/exhibits/treasures/trr072.html | accessdate = June 9, 2008 }} </ref>
Harrison's doctors tried cures, applying [[opium]], [[castor oil]], [[leeches]], and [[Aristolochia serpentaria|Virginia snakeroot]]. But the treatments only made Harrison worse, and he became delirious. He died nine days after becoming ill,<ref>Cleaves 160</ref> at 12:30 am on April 4, 1841, of right lower lobe [[pneumonia]], [[jaundice]], and overwhelming [[septicemia]]. He was the first United States president to die in office. His last words were to his doctor, but assumed to be directed at Vice President [[John Tyler]], "Sir, I wish you to understand the true principles of the government. I wish them carried out. I ask nothing more." Harrison served the shortest term of any American president: March 4 – April 4, 1841, 30 days, 12 hours, and 30 minutes.<ref name="dyingstmt">{{cite web |title=President Harrison Dies – April 4, 1841 |year=2008 |work=Events in Presidential History |publisher=Miller Center, University of Virginia |url=http://millercenter.org/academic/americanpresident/events/04_04 |accessdate=February 16, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140715035833/http://millercenter.org/academic/americanpresident/events/04_04 |archivedate=July 15, 2014 }} </ref><ref name="Diamond 1976">{{cite book | title = Congressional Quarterly's Guide to U.S. Elections | publisher = Congressional Quarterly Inc | year = 1976 | isbn = 978-0-87187-072-8 | page = 492 | author = ed.: Robert A. Diamond ... Major contributors: Rhodes Cook ... }} </ref>
Harrison's funeral took place in the [[Wesley Chapel (Cincinnati)|Wesley Chapel]] in [[Cincinnati]], Ohio, on April 7, 1841.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.whha.org/presentations/presidential-funerals/presidential-funerals-william-henry-harrison.html|title=William Henry Harrison|accessdate=July 26, 2014|publisher=[[White House Historical Association]]}}</ref> His original interment was in the public vault of the [[Congressional Cemetery]] in Washington, D.C. He was later buried in [[North Bend, Ohio]]. The [[William Henry Harrison Tomb State Memorial]] was erected in his honor.<ref name="ohiohistory tomb">{{cite web |publisher=Ohio Historical Society |title=Harrison Tomb |url=http://ohsweb.ohiohistory.org/places/sw11/ |accessdate=June 9, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130514205716/http://ohsweb.ohiohistory.org/places/sw11/ |archivedate=May 14, 2013 }} </ref>
==1850: Zachary Taylor== [[File:Zachary Taylor Grave.JPG|thumb|left|alt=A photograph of a grey-bricked building with golden double doors under an engraving reading "ZACHARY TAYLOR" all under a cloudy, blue sky|Taylor's mausoleum at the [[Zachary Taylor National Cemetery]] in Louisville, Kentucky]] On July 4, 1850, Taylor was known to have consumed copious amounts of ice water, cold milk, green apples, and cherries after attending holiday celebrations and the laying of the cornerstone of the [[Washington Monument]].<ref>{{cite book | last1 = Eisenhower | first1 = John S.D. | title = Zachary Taylor The American Presidents | publisher = Macmillan | year = 2008 | pages = 132–3 | isbn = 978-0805082371}}</ref> That same evening, he became severely ill with an unknown digestive ailment. Doctors used popular treatments of the time. Taylor died in the White House at 10:35 p.m. on July 9, five days after becoming ill.<ref>Bauer, pp. 314–316.</ref> Contemporary reports listed the cause of death as "[[bilious diarrhea]], or a bilious cholera".<ref>{{cite news|title=Death of the President of the United States|accessdate=October 17, 2011|newspaper=Boston Daily Evening Transcript |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=730-AAAAIBAJ&sjid=yFkMAAAIBAJ&dq=zachary%20taylor%20dead&pg=6596%2C286648 |date=July 10, 1850}}</ref> He was succeeded by Vice President [[Millard Fillmore]].
The cause of [[Zachary Taylor]]'s death was fully established in 2001.<ref name="history">{{cite book|title=History as Mystery|last=Parenti|first=Michael|date=September 1999|publisher=City Light Books|isbn=978-0-87286-357-6|page=304|authorlink=Michael Parenti}}</ref> Almost immediately after his death, rumors began to circulate that Taylor was poisoned by pro-slavery Southerners, and similar theories persisted into the twentieth century.<ref>{{cite book|last=Willard and Marion|title=Killing the President|year=2010|page=188}}</ref> The remains were exhumed and transported to the Office of the [[Kentucky]] Chief Medical Examiner on June 17, 1991. [[Neutron activation analysis]] conducted at [[Oak Ridge National Laboratory]] revealed no evidence of poisoning, as [[arsenic]] levels were too low.<ref name="Marriott">{{cite news|last=Marriott|first=Michel|title=Verdict In: 12th President Was Not Assassinated|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/27/us/verdict-in-12th-president-was-not-assassinated.html?ref=zacharytaylor17841850|accessdate=October 17, 2011|newspaper=The New York Times|date=June 27, 2011}}</ref><ref name="ORNL">{{cite web|url=http://www.ornl.gov/info/ornlreview/rev27-12/text/ansside6.html |title=President Zachary Taylor and the Laboratory: Presidential Visit from the Grave |publisher=Oak Ridge National Laboratory |accessdate=November 2, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100728065612/http://www.ornl.gov/info/ornlreview/rev27-12/text/ansside6.html |archivedate=July 28, 2010 |df= }}</ref> The analysis concluded Taylor had contracted "[[cholera morbus]], or [[acute gastroenteritis]]", as Washington had open sewers, and his food or drink may have been contaminated.<ref name="Sampas">{{cite news|last=Sampas|first=Jim|title=Scandal and the Heat Did Zachary Taylor In|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/04/opinion/l-scandal-and-the-heat-did-zachary-taylor-in-998691.html?ref=zacharytaylor17841850|accessdate=October 17, 2011|newspaper=The New York Times|date=July 4, 1991}}</ref>
Taylor was interred in the Public Vault of the [[Congressional Cemetery]] in Washington, D.C. from July 13, 1850 to October 25, 1850. (It was built in 1835 to hold remains of notables until either the grave site could be prepared or transportation arranged to another city.) His body was transported to the Taylor Family plot where his parents are buried, on the old Taylor homestead plantation known as 'Springfield' in Louisville, Kentucky.<ref>{{Cite book|page=134|title=The Corpse: A History|author=Christine Quigley|publisher=[[McFarland & Company]]|year=2005|isbn=0786424494}}</ref>
==1865: Abraham Lincoln== [[File:Lincoln assassination slide c1900.png|thumb|left|alt=Image of Lincoln being shot by Booth while sitting in a theater booth.|Shown in the presidential booth of Ford's Theatre, from left to right, are assassin [[John Wilkes Booth]], Abraham Lincoln, [[Mary Todd Lincoln]], [[Clara Harris]], and [[Henry Rathbone]]]] {{main|Assassination of Abraham Lincoln}} The assassination of [[Abraham Lincoln]] took place on [[Good Friday]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nhpr.org/node/15187. |title=Good Friday, 1865: Lincoln’s Last Day|author=|publisher=[[NPHR STAFF]]|date=2008-02-18|accessdate=2011-05-31}}</ref> April 14, 1865, as the [[American Civil War]] was drawing to a close. The assassination occurred five days after the commanding [[General]] of the [[Army of Northern Virginia]], [[Robert E. Lee]], surrendered to [[General]] [[Ulysses S. Grant]] and the [[Army of the Potomac]]. Lincoln was the first American president to be assassinated,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://memory.loc.gov/ammem/today/apr14.html|publisher=[[Library of Congress]]|title=Lincoln Shot at Ford's Theater|accessdate=September 6, 2012}}</ref> though an unsuccessful attempt had been made on [[Andrew Jackson]] 30 years before in 1835.<ref>[[Sean Wilentz|Wilentz, Sean]]. ''Andrew Jackson'' (2005), p. 8, 35.</ref>
The assassination of Lincoln was planned and carried out by the well-known stage actor [[John Wilkes Booth]], a [[Confederate States of America|Confederate]] sympathizer, vehement in his denunciation of Lincoln, and a strong opponent of the [[Abolitionism in the United States|abolition]] of [[slavery in the United States]].<ref name="NYTltr">{{cite news|title=The murderer of Mr. Lincoln|work=The New York Times|date=April 21, 1865|url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1865/04/21/78997175.pdf | format=PDF}}</ref> Booth and a group of co-conspirators originally plotted to kidnap Lincoln, but later planned to kill him, [[Vice President of the United States|Vice President]] [[Andrew Johnson]], and [[United States Secretary of State|Secretary of State]] [[William H. Seward]] in a bid to help the Confederacy's cause.<ref>Hamner, Christopher. "[http://teachinghistory.org/history-content/ask-a-historian/24242 Booth's Reason for Assassination] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101202112805/http://teachinghistory.org/history-content/ask-a-historian/24242 |date=December 2, 2010 }}." [http://www.teachinghistory.org Teachinghistory.org]. Accessed 12 July 2011.</ref> (Vice President Johnson's assailant did not carry out his part of the plan, and Johnson succeeded Lincoln as President.)
Lincoln was shot once in the back of his head while watching the play ''[[Our American Cousin]]'' with his wife [[Mary Todd Lincoln]] at [[Ford's Theatre]] in [[Washington, D.C.]] at around 10:15 pm on the night of April 14, 1865.<ref>{{Cite book|page=346|author=Phillip B. Kunhardt Jr. |author2=Phillip Kunhardt III |author3=[[Peter Kunhardt]]|title=Lincoln: An Illustrated Biography|publisher=Gramercy Books|location=New York|year=1992|isbn=0-517-20715-X}}</ref> An army surgeon who happened to be at Ford's, Doctor [[Charles Leale]], assessed Lincoln's wound as mortal.<ref>{{Cite book|author=James Swanson|title=Manhunt: The 12-Day Chase for Lincoln's Killer|publisher=Harper Collins|year=2006|isbn=978-0-06-051849-3|page=78}}</ref> The unconscious President was then carried across the street from the theater to the [[Petersen House]], where he remained in a coma for nine hours before dying the following morning at 7:22 a.m. on April 15.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://memory.loc.gov/ammem/alhtml/alrintr.html |title=Lincoln Papers: Lincoln Assassination: Introduction |publisher=Memory.loc.gov |accessdate=2013-10-14}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://rogerjnorton.com/Lincoln7.html |title=Henry Safford |publisher=rogerjnorton.com |accessdate=May 28, 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110601201201/http://rogerjnorton.com/Lincoln7.html| archivedate=June 1, 2011}}</ref><ref name="Heritage">{{cite journal|title=How Did Lincoln Die?|journal=American Heritage|date=February–March 1995|volume=46|issue=1|url=http://www.americanheritage.com/content/how-did-lincoln-die?page=show|author=Richard A. R. Fraser, MD}}</ref>
==1881: James A. Garfield== [[File:Garfield assassination engraving cropped.jpg|thumb|alt=A black-and-white drawing of a crowd of people, some of whom are angry, the two foremost of whom are bearded and wearing top hats|President Garfield with [[James G. Blaine]] after being shot by [[Charles J. Guiteau]]<ref>{{Cite journal|author=Lynne Vincent Cheney|url=http://www.americanheritage.com/articles/magazine/ah/1975/6/1975_6_42.shtml|title=Mrs. Frank Leslie's Illustrated Newspaper|journal=American Heritage Magazine|date=October 1975|volume=26|issue=6|accessdate=January 24, 2007|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091106160357/http://www.americanheritage.com/articles/magazine/ah/1975/6/1975_6_42.shtml|archivedate=November 6, 2009}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://lcweb2.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/D?presp:4:./temp/~ammem_d2P8|title=The attack on the President's life|publisher=Library of Congress|accessdate=January 24, 2007}}</ref>]] {{main|Assassination of James A. Garfield}} The [[assassination]] of [[James A. Garfield]] took place in [[Washington, D.C.]] on July 2, 1881. Garfield was shot by [[Charles J. Guiteau]] at 9:30 am, less than four months into Garfield's term as the 20th [[President of the United States]]. Garfield died eleven weeks later on September 19, 1881. His [[Vice President of the United States|Vice President]], [[Chester A. Arthur]], succeeded Garfield as President. Garfield also lived the longest after the shooting, compared to other assassinated Presidents. Garfield was scheduled to leave Washington on July 2, 1881 for his summer vacation.<ref>Peskin 581</ref> On that day, Guiteau lay in wait for the President at the [[Baltimore and Potomac Railroad]] station, on the southwest corner of present-day Sixth Street and Constitution Avenue NW, [[Washington, D.C.]]<ref name="Conwell">{{cite book | author=George Stinson Conwell | title=The life, speeches, and public services of James A. Garfield, twentieth President of the United States : including an account of his assassination, lingering pain, death and burial | location=Portland, Maine | oclc=2087548 | pages=349 }}</ref>
President Garfield came to the Sixth Street Station on his way to his [[alma mater]], [[Williams College]], where he was scheduled to deliver a speech. Garfield was accompanied by two of his sons, [[James Rudolph Garfield|James]] and [[Harry Augustus Garfield|Harry]], and [[United States Secretary of State|Secretary of State]] [[James G. Blaine|Blaine]]. [[United States Secretary of War|Secretary of War]] [[Robert Todd Lincoln]] waited at the station to see the President off.<ref name="Vowell 160">Vowell 160</ref> Garfield had no bodyguard or security detail; with the exception of Abraham Lincoln during the [[United States Civil War|Civil War]], early U.S. presidents never used any guards.<ref name="Peskin 593">Peskin 593</ref>
As President Garfield entered the waiting room of the station Guiteau stepped forward and pulled the trigger from behind at point-blank range. "My God, what is that?" Garfield cried out, flinging up his arms. Guiteau fired again and Garfield collapsed.<ref name="Peskin 596">Peskin 596</ref> One bullet grazed Garfield's shoulder; the other hit him in the back, passing the first [[Lumbar vertebrae|lumbar vertebra]] but missing the [[spinal cord]] before coming to rest behind his pancreas.<ref>Millard 189, 312</ref>
Garfield, conscious but in shock, was carried to an upstairs floor of the train station.<ref>Peskin 596–597</ref> One bullet remained lodged in his body, but doctors could not find it.<ref name="Peskin 597">Peskin 597</ref> Young Jim Garfield and James Blaine both broke down and wept. Robert Todd Lincoln, deeply upset and thinking back to the death of his father, said "How many hours of sorrow I have passed in this town."<ref name="Peskin 597" />
Garfield was carried back to the White House. Although doctors told him that he would not survive the night, the President remained conscious and alert.<ref>Peskin 598</ref> The next morning his vital signs were good and doctors began to hope for recovery.<ref>Peskin 599</ref> A long vigil began, with Garfield's doctors issuing regular bulletins that the American public followed closely throughout the summer of 1881.<ref>Peskin 600</ref><ref>Vowell 124</ref> His condition fluctuated. Fevers came and went. Garfield struggled to keep down solid food and spent most of the summer eating little, and that only liquids.<ref>Peskin 601</ref>
Garfield had been a regular visitor to the shore town of [[Long Branch, New Jersey]], one of the nation's premier summer vacation spots until World War I. In early September, it was decided to bring him to [[Elberon, New Jersey|Elberon]], a quiet beach town just to the south of Long Branch, in hopes that the beach air would help him recover. When they heard that the president was being brought to their town, local citizens built more than half a mile of tracks in less than 24 hours, enabling Garfield to be brought directly to the door of the oceanfront Franklyn cottage, rather than being moved by carriage from the local Elberon train station. However, Garfield died 12 days later. A granite marker on Garfield Rd identifies the former site of the cottage, which was demolished in 1950.
Chester Arthur was at his home in New York City on the night of September 19, when word came that Garfield had died. After first getting the news, Arthur said "I hope—my God, I do hope it is a mistake." But confirmation by telegram came soon after. Arthur took the presidential oath of office, administered by a [[New York Supreme Court]] judge, then left for Long Branch to pay his respects before traveling on to Washington.<ref>Peskin 608</ref> Garfield's body was taken to Washington, where it lay in state for two days in the Capitol Rotunda before being taken to Cleveland, where the funeral was held on September 26.<ref>Peskin 608–609</ref>
When the tracks that had been hastily built to the Franklyn cottage were later torn up, actor Oliver Byron bought the wooden ties, and had local carpenter William Presley build them into a small tea house, in commemoration of the president. The red & white (originally red, white & blue) "Garfield Tea House" still survives, resting a couple of blocks away from the site of the cottage on the grounds of the Long Branch Historical Museum, a former Episcopal Church. The church is nicknamed "The Church of the Presidents", as it had been attended by, in addition to Garfield, Presidents Chester A. Arthur, Ulysses S. Grant, Benjamin Harrison, Rutherford Hayes, William McKinley, and Woodrow Wilson, during their own visits to Long Branch.
==1901: William McKinley== [[File:McKinleyAssassination.jpg|thumb|left|alt=A black-and-white drawing of a crowd of people, one of whom is being watched by all the others, all standing under a draped banner|[[Leon Czolgosz]] shoots [[president of the United States|President]] [[William McKinley|McKinley]] with a concealed revolver. Clipping of a wash drawing by T. Dart Walker.]] {{main|Assassination of William McKinley}} [[William McKinley]] was assassinated on September 6, 1901, inside the [[Temple of Music]] on the grounds of the [[Pan-American Exposition]] in [[Buffalo, New York|Buffalo]], New York. [[William McKinley|McKinley]] was shaking hands with the public when he was shot by [[Leon Czolgosz]], an [[Anarchism|anarchist]]. The President died eight days later on September 14 from [[gangrene]] caused by the bullet wounds.<ref name=McKinley>Leech 594-600</ref>
McKinley had been [[United States presidential election, 1900|elected for a second term in 1900]].<ref>{{cite book | last = Rauchway | first = Eric | authorlink=Eric Rauchway | year = 2004 | title = Murdering McKinley: The Making of Theodore Roosevelt's America | publisher = Hill and Wang | location = New York | pages = 3–4 | isbn = 978-0-8090-1638-9 | ref = {{sfnRef|Rauchway}} }}</ref> He enjoyed meeting the public, and was reluctant to accept the security available to his office.<ref>Leech 561-62</ref> The [[Secretary to the President of the United States|Secretary to the President]], [[George B. Cortelyou]], feared an [[assassination]] attempt would take place during a visit to the Temple of Music, and twice took it off the schedule. McKinley restored it each time.<ref>Leech 584</ref>
Czolgosz had lost his job during the economic [[Panic of 1893]] and turned to anarchism, a political philosophy whose adherents had killed foreign leaders.<ref>Miller 56-60</ref> Regarding McKinley as a symbol of oppression, Czolgosz felt it was his duty as an anarchist to kill him.<ref>Miller 301–302</ref> Unable to get near McKinley during the earlier part of the presidential visit, Czolgosz shot McKinley twice as the President reached to shake his hand in the reception line at the temple. One bullet grazed McKinley; the other entered his abdomen and was never found.<ref name=McKinley/>
McKinley initially appeared to be recovering, but took a turn for the worse on September 13 as his wounds became gangrenous, and died early the next morning; [[Vice President of the United States|Vice President]] [[Theodore Roosevelt]] succeeded him. Roosevelt was hiking near the top of [[Mt. Marcy]], in New York State's [[Adirondacks|Adirondack]] region, when a runner located him to convey the news.<ref>{{cite book | last = Morgan | first = H. Wayne | year = 2003 | title = William McKinley and His America |edition=revised | publisher = The Kent State University Press | page = 402 | location = Kent, Ohio | isbn = 978-0-87338-765-1 | ref = {{sfnRef|Morgan}} }}</ref> After McKinley's murder, for which Czolgosz was put to death in the [[electric chair]], the [[United States Congress]] passed legislation to officially charge the [[United States Secret Service|Secret Service]] with the responsibility for protecting the president.<ref>{{cite book | last = Bumgarner | first = Jeffrey | year = 2006 | title = Federal Agents: The Growth of Federal Law Enforcement in America | publisher = Greenwood Press | page = 46 | location = Westport, Connecticut | isbn = 978-0-275-98953-8 | ref = {{sfnRef|Bumgarner}} }}</ref>
==1923: Warren G. Harding== [[Image:HardingFuneral.jpg|thumb|alt=A black-and-white photograph of a procession of people in uniforms, some of whom are riding horses, all standing in front of a white building|Funeral procession for President Harding passes by the front of the [[White House]]]] [[Warren G. Harding]] died from a sudden heart attack in his hotel suite while visiting [[San Francisco]] at around 7:35 p.m. on August 2, 1923. His death quickly led to theories that he had been poisoned<ref name="death">{{cite web|url=http://www.cnsspectrums.com/aspx/articledetail.aspx?articleid=605|title=Presidential Stroke: United States Presidents and Cerebrovascular Disease (Warren G. Harding) |author=Jeffrey M. Jones |author2=Joni L. Jones |work=CNS Spectrums |accessdate=July 20, 2011}}</ref> or committed suicide. Rumors of poisoning were fueled, in part, by a book called ''The Strange Death of President Harding,'' in which the author (convicted criminal, former Ohio Gang member, and detective [[Gaston Means]], hired by Mrs. Harding to investigate Warren Harding and his mistress) suggested that Mrs. Harding had poisoned her husband after learning of his infidelity. Mrs. Harding's refusal to allow an autopsy on President Harding only added to the speculation. According to the physicians attending Harding, however, the symptoms in the days prior to his death all pointed to [[congestive heart failure]]. Harding's biographer, Samuel H. Adams, concluded that "Warren G. Harding died a natural death which, in any case, could not have been long postponed".<ref>Adams (1939, 1964), ''Incredible Era'', pp. 377–384</ref>
Immediately after President Harding's death, Mrs. Harding returned to [[Washington, D.C.]], and briefly stayed in the White House with the new President [[Calvin Coolidge]] and First Lady. For a month, former First Lady Harding gathered and destroyed by fire President Harding's correspondence and documents, both official and unofficial. Upon her return to [[Marion, Ohio]], Mrs. Harding hired a number of secretaries to collect and burn President Harding's personal papers. According to Mrs. Harding, she took these actions to protect her husband's legacy. The remaining papers were held and kept from public view by the ''Harding Memorial Association'' in Marion.<ref>Russell (April 1963), ''The Four Mysteries Of Warren Harding''</ref>
==1945: Franklin D. Roosevelt== On March 29, 1945, [[Franklin D. Roosevelt]] went to the [[Little White House]] in [[Warm Springs, Georgia]], to rest before his anticipated appearance at the [[United Nations Conference on International Organization|founding conference]] of the [[United Nations]] in late April in San Francisco. On the afternoon of April 12, Roosevelt said, "I have a terrific pain in the back of my head." He then slumped forward in his chair, unconscious, and was carried into his bedroom. The president's attending cardiologist, Dr. Howard Bruenn, diagnosed a massive [[cerebral hemorrhage]] (stroke).<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.cnsspectrums.com/aspx/articledetail.aspx?articleid=605|title=Presidential Stroke: United States Presidents and Cerebrovascular Disease (Franklin D. Roosevelt)| first=Jeffrey M.|last=Jones |author2=Joni L. Jones |work=CNS Spectrums |accessdate= July 20, 2011}}</ref> At 3:35 pm that day, Roosevelt died without regaining consciousness. As [[Allen Drury]] later said, "so ended an era, and so began another." After Roosevelt's death, an editorial by ''The New York Times'' declared, "Men will thank God on their knees a hundred years from now that Franklin D. Roosevelt was in the White House".<ref>{{cite news|title=Person of the Century Runner-Up: Franklin Delano Roosevelt|publisher=Time|url=http://www.time.com/time/time100/poc/magazine/franklin_delano_rooseve9a.html|accessdate=October 9, 2008|date=March 1, 2000|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091110120453/http://www.time.com/time/time100/poc/magazine/franklin_delano_rooseve9a.html|archivedate=November 10, 2009}}</ref>
[[Image:Franklin Roosevelt funeral procession 1945.jpg|thumb|right|alt=A black-and-white photograph of a wagon being drawn and accompanied by seven white horses, some of which are being ridden by people|Roosevelt's horse-drawn casket proceeds down [[Pennsylvania Avenue (Washington, D.C.)|Pennsylvania Avenue]] during his funeral procession.]] In his later years at the White House, when Roosevelt was increasingly overworked, his daughter [[Anna E. Roosevelt|Anna Roosevelt Boettiger]] had moved in to provide her father companionship and support. Anna had also arranged for her father to meet with his former mistress, the now widowed [[Lucy Page Mercer Rutherfurd|Lucy Mercer Rutherfurd]]. A close friend of both Roosevelt and Mercer who was present, [[Elizabeth Shoumatoff]], rushed Mercer away to avoid negative publicity and implications of infidelity. When Eleanor heard about her husband's death, she was also faced with the news that Anna had been arranging these meetings with Mercer and that Mercer had been with Franklin when he died.<ref>{{Cite book|title=A Companion to Franklin D. Roosevelt|author=William D. Pederson|publisher=[[John Wiley & Sons]]|year=2011|isbn=1444395173}}</ref>
On the morning of April 13, Roosevelt's body was placed in a flag-draped coffin and loaded onto the presidential train. After a White House funeral on April 14, Roosevelt was transported back to Hyde Park by train, guarded by four servicemen, one each from the Army, Navy, Marines, and Coast Guard. As was his wish, Roosevelt was buried in the Rose Garden of the [[Home of Franklin D. Roosevelt National Historic Site|Springwood estate]], the Roosevelt family home in Hyde Park on April 15. Eleanor died in November 1962 and was buried next to him.<ref>{{Cite journal|page=999|title=Roosevelt, Eleanor|author=Margaret Prentice Hecker|journal=Encyclopedia of African American History|volume=1|editor=Leslie Alexander|publisher=[[ABC-CLIO]]|year=2010|isbn=1851097694}}</ref>
Roosevelt's death was met with shock and grief<ref>{{cite video|year=1945|title=Video: Allies Overrun Germany (1945)|url=https://archive.org/details/gov.archives.arc.39165|publisher=[[Universal Newsreel]]|accessdate=February 21, 2012}}</ref> across the U.S. and around the world. His declining health had not been known to the general public. Roosevelt had been president for more than 12 years, longer than any other person, and had led the country through some of its greatest crises to the impending defeat of Nazi Germany and within sight of the defeat of Japan as well.
Less than a month after his death, on May 8, the war in Europe ended. President [[Harry S. Truman]], who turned 61 that day, dedicated [[Victory in Europe Day]] and its celebrations to Roosevelt's memory, and kept the flags across the U.S. at half-staff for the remainder of the 30-day mourning period. In doing so, Truman said that his only wish was "that Franklin D. Roosevelt had lived to witness this day."<ref>McCullough 345, 381</ref>
==1963: John F. Kennedy== [[File:John F. Kennedy motorcade, Dallas crop.png|thumb|JFK, Jackie, and the Connallys in the presidential limousine minutes before the [[Assassination of John F. Kennedy|assassination]]]] {{main|Assassination of John F. Kennedy}} [[John F. Kennedy]] was assassinated at 12:30 p.m. Central Standard Time (18:30 [[Coordinated Universal Time|UTC]]) on Friday, November 22, 1963, in [[Dealey Plaza]], [[Dallas]], Texas.<ref name="aarclibrary.org">[http://www.aarclibrary.org/publib/jfk/wc/wcvols/wh4/html/WC_Vol4_0078a.htm Warren Commission Testimony of Nellie Connally], vol. 4, p. 147.</ref><ref>[http://www.aarclibrary.org/publib/jfk/wc/wcvols/wh4/html/WC_Vol4_0070a.htm Warren Commission Testimony of John B. Connally], vol. 4, pp. 131–132.</ref> Kennedy was fatally shot while traveling with his wife [[Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis|Jacqueline]], [[Governor of Texas|Texas Governor]] [[John Connally]], and the latter's wife [[Nellie Connally|Nellie]], in a Presidential [[motorcade]]. The ten-month investigation by the [[Warren Commission]] of 1963–1964 concluded that President Kennedy was assassinated by [[Lee Harvey Oswald]] and that Oswald had acted entirely alone. It also concluded that [[Jack Ruby]] acted alone when he killed Oswald in police custody. Nonetheless, polls conducted from 1966 to 2004 found that as many as 80 percent of Americans have suspected that there was a plot or [[cover-up]].<ref name="langer20031116">{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/images/pdf/937a1JFKAssassination.pdf|author=Gary Langer|title=John F. Kennedy's Assassination Leaves a Legacy of Suspicion|publisher=ABC News|date=November 16, 2003|accessdate=May 16, 2010}}</ref><ref>Jarrett Murphy, [http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2003/11/20/national/main584668.shtml 40 Years Later: Who Killed JFK?], CBS News, November 21, 2003.</ref>
Most current [[John F. Kennedy assassination conspiracy theories]] put forth a criminal [[conspiracy (crime)|conspiracy]] involving parties as varied as the [[Central Intelligence Agency|CIA]], the [[American Mafia|Mafia]], anti-Castro [[Cuban exile]] groups, the [[military industrial complex]], sitting [[Vice President of the United States|Vice President]] [[Lyndon B. Johnson]], [[President of Cuba|Cuban President]] [[Fidel Castro]], [[Federal Bureau of Investigation|FBI]] director [[J. Edgar Hoover]], the [[KGB]], or some combination of those entities.<ref>{{cite book|last=Summers|first=Anthony|title=Not in Your Lifetime|year=2013|publisher=Open Road|location=New York|isbn=978-1-4804-3548-3|chapter=Six Options for History|page=238|url=http://www.openroadmedia.com/not-in-your-lifetime|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131101151417/http://www.openroadmedia.com/not-in-your-lifetime|archivedate=November 1, 2013|df=mdy-all}}</ref> In an article published prior to the 50th anniversary of Kennedy's assassination, author [[Vincent Bugliosi]] estimates that a total of 42 groups, 82 assassins, and 214 people have been accused in conspiracy theories challenging the "lone gunman" theory.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://edition.cnn.com/2013/11/16/us/jfk-assassination-conspiracy-theories-debunked/ | work=CNN | title=One JFK conspiracy theory that could be true - CNN.com | date=November 18, 2013}}</ref>

Jack |title=Zachary Taylor: Soldier, Planter, Statesman of the Old Southwest |publisher=[[Louisiana State University Press]] |year=1985 |isbn=0-8071-1237-2 |ref=Bauer}} *{{Cite book|author=Cleaves, Freeman|title=Old Tippecanoe: William Henry Harrison and His Time|publisher=C. Scribner's Sons|location=New York, NY|year=1939}} *{{cite book | last = Leech | first = Margaret | authorlink = Margaret Leech | year = 1959 | title = In the Days of McKinley | publisher = Harper and Brothers | pages = 594–600 | location = New York | oclc = 456809}} * {{Cite book |ref=McCullough |last=McCullough |first=David | year=1992 | authorlink=David McCullough |title = [[Truman (book)|Truman]] | publisher=Simon & Schuster |isbn= 0-671-86920-5}} *{{Cite book|author=[[Candice Millard|Millard, Candice]]|title=Destiny of the Republic|publisher=Doubleday|year=2011|isbn=978-0-385-53500-7}} *{{cite book | last = Miller | first = Scott | year = 2011 | title = The President and the Assassin | publisher = Random House | pages = 56–60 | location = New York | isbn = 978-1-4000-6752-7}} *{{Cite book|author=Peskin, Allan|title=Garfield|year=1978|publisher=Kent State University Press|isbn=0-87338-210-2}} *{{Cite book|author=[[Sarah Vowell|Vowell, Sarah]]|title=[[Assassination Vacation]]|publisher=Simon and Schuster|year=2005|isbn=0-7432-6003-1}}

page.title: List of unidentified murder victims in the United States

revision.comment: /* Floyd County John Doe */ Word str.
revision.text:
{{For|a list of unidentified decedents in general|List of unidentified decedents in the United States}} {{short description|Wikimedia list article}} {{Use American English|date=September 2014}} {{Use mdy dates|date=December 2017}} [[File:Walker County ID photo fx Recon 007b.jpg|150px|thumb|The [[Walker County Jane Doe]] is an unidentified murder victim found in Texas. She was aged between 14 and 20 when she died on October 31 or November 1, 1980. Her identity remains unknown]] [[File:1968-01481 Reconstruction 002.jpg|150px|thumb|[[Los Angeles County John Doe (1968)|Los Angeles County John Doe]], who was found in California on February 9, 1968]]
Of the thousands of people [[murder]]ed every year in the United States, several remain [[unidentified decedent|unidentified]]. Many of these individuals remain unidentified for years or even decades after their deaths. Cases include that of [[Murder of Tammy Alexander|Tammy Jo Alexander]], who was murdered in 1979 and remained an [[unidentified decedent]] until 2015,<ref name=dem>{{cite news |title = Police ID 'Jane Doe' found in Livingston Co. cornfield in 1979 |url = http://www.democratandchronicle.com/story/news/2015/01/26/jane-doe-caledonia/22342077/ |accessdate = January 26, 2015 |date = January 26, 2015 }}</ref> and [[Murder of Reet Jurvetson|Reet Jurvetson]], who was murdered in 1969 and whose body remained unidentified for 46 years.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://people.com/crime/lapd-seeks-to-identify-two-men-in-connection-with-murder-of-reet-jurvetson/ |title=L.A. Cops Search for Two in 1969 Unsolved Murder of Reet Jurvetson; Say No Charles Manson Connection |date=2016-09-08 |accessdate=2018-08-02}}</ref>
Including murder victims and those who died via [[Death by natural causes|natural causes]] or otherwise, approximately 40,000 decedents remain unidentified in the United States.<ref name=coldcasesonline>{{cite news |last1 = Goldman |first1 = Abigial |title = Cold Cases Go Online, with Respect for Victims |url = http://www.lasvegassun.com/news/2008/feb/10/cold-cases-go-online-respect-victims/ |accessdate = August 11, 2014 |agency = Las Vegas Sun |date = February 10, 2008 }}</ref><ref name=bone>{{cite news |last1 = Olsen |first1 = Lise |title = 'Detective' will exhume bodies in victim identity hunt |url = http://www.chron.com/news/houston-texas/article/Detective-will-exhume-bodies-in-victim-identity-1691577.php#ixzz1Nx3nb9AT |accessdate = December 8, 2014 |work = Houston Chronicle |date = May 30, 2011 }}</ref>
== Alabama == {{anchor|Tuscaloosa County Jane Doe}} {{external media | width = | image1 =[http://doenetwork.org/cases/images/108UFAL1.jpg Sketch] |image2 = [http://doenetwork.org/cases/images/108UFAL.jpg Second sketch] }}
=== Tuscaloosa County Jane Doe === Tuscaloosa County Jane Doe is a white female aged between 34 and 38 whose body was found in Slaughter Creek, near the Sipsey River in [[Romulus, Alabama|Romulus, Tuscaloosa County]] on April 18, 1982.<ref>{{cite news |author1 = Reynolds, Kelvin |author2 = Britzius, Brianne |title = Tuscaloosa authorities exhume body in hopes of solving 1982 murder |url = http://www.myfoxal.com/story/24036804/tuscaloosa-authorities-exhume-body-in-hopes-of-solving-1982-murder |accessdate = December 4, 2014 |work = My Fox Local |agency = Fox News |date = November 21, 2013 }}</ref> She had been beaten, [[strangulation|strangled]] and sexually assaulted.
